prompt: Years ago, you donated your “genetic material” to a secret organization in exchange for $30 million. Now, years later, there’s a knock on your door, and you find yourself face-to-face with a group of superpowered teenagers claiming you’re their father.
ground_truth:
$30 million for my DNA? Of course I took that deal. I could put just $2 million in the bank and live off the interest, $30 million would set me up for life, and my children, and my children’s children and, if we invested smartly, they’re children too. You may think that was crazy and really shady, which was my thought too, but it was all legit. The doctor was genuine, the contract official and the government agent who greeted me too. They said I appeared to be the “ideal subject” for their experiments. So a blood donation, cheek swab and… ahem other donation later and I was $30 million richer, well actually they gave me quite a bit more. Went back to Britain and lived my life normally, well I did once I explained to the fraud investigators where I’d got the money from and paid my taxes for the massive income, putting me down to exactly $30 million or £23,653,350.
I hired a financial advisor and invested the money smartly. I paid off the mortgage, my student debt and the huge list of other debts I had to pay, barely made a dent. Then I got the teaching job I’d always wanted. Money was no longer an issue, I simply took some of the interest of my investments and used it to supplement my income. Life was good, didn’t really tell anyone about my good fortune, but close friends and family always got good gifts on birthdays and Christmas. I found a wife, got a couple of children, biological and adopted. I’d say I almost forgot the incident, but it’s hard to forgot the thing that is funding your lifestyle.
About 20 years passed before the consequences showed up at my front door, literally and figuratively. I was home sick with a bug I’m pretty sure my daughters brought home and waiting for the microwave to finish with my soup when a knock on the door sounded through the house. Despite having no reason to, I had a bad feeling about it, so bad I ended up picking up one of the kitchen knives as I made my way to the door, opening the door just a crack, bracing it against my foot and peaking through.
A small gaggle of teenagers stood on the doorstep. They looked normal enough, wearing your standard teenage clothes. The youngest, maybe 12, wore a pink top with those sequins that made a different image depending if the sequins were pushed up and down. She was looking at it in awe and wonder as she cycled between the pony and castle. Then there was a maybe 14 year old who wore a tracksuit and joggers, looking like your typical chav. A 15 year old with a flowery dress and a jacket over the top and mismatched socks with her sandals and finally an 18 year old with smart trousers and a standard blue striped T-shirt with waistcoat stood at the front, smiling at me. Their clothes were a tad mismatched at times but they looked normal enough. I started to feel a little silly about bringing a knife before I noticed the tags and security tags still on their clothes. They were clearly thieves, so what were they doing here? My intrusive thoughts took over as I scanned for weapons, but found none as the 18 year old spoke.
“H-hello,” he said nervously, “this is going to sound crazy, but in your son.”
I raised my eyebrow at him. “No you aren’t. I haven’t had sex with anyone except my wife. And I definitely haven’t donated…” I froze, remembering when I donated my DNA. I looked at them closely and recognised a lot of my features in them, the blonde slightly curly hair, except for the 12 year old who’s hair was blue and pink, the blue eyes and the oh so recognisable bump on the bridge of their nose that my mother had given me.
The 18 year old nodded. “Yes, we’re your children.”
“You get my ADHD?”
The kid shook his head. “No, we got autism.”
“Correct,” I had needed to test them, in case they were lying, “come on in.” I opened the door wider and beckoned them in.
They followed me to the kitchen where I kept microwaving my soup and collapsed into the chair, even the small exertion of standing in the doorway wiping me out with my illness.
“So, why would the American government want to make children with my DNA?”
The kids all moved awkwardly to take different spaces in the kitchen. The 14 year old hopped up on the worktop while the 15 year old started rooting through the cupboards.
“Uh, not exactly.” The 18 year old said. “They wanted to make soldiers.”
“Soldiers?” My blood ran cold at the thought. “And why would I be the ‘perfect candidate?”
“No physical conditions of any kind, you were a ‘blank slate’.” I wasn’t sure how to feel about that, was it a compliment? But that wasn’t important at the moment.
I scowled. “And you’re their ‘soldiers’. Children.”
The 18 year old nodded, holding out his hand a conjuring a small flame in it. I almost fell out of my chair in shock as the flame appeared. The 15 year old slapped the 18 year old, who looked sheepish.
“Way to ease him into it,” she told him off.
I pointed to the flame. “How the Heck did you do that?!”
The flame vanished as the 18 year old held his hands up placatingly. “The government wanted more than soldier, they wanted super soldiers. So the experimented with your DNA. I was their first success. My body naturally produces several flammable substances, liquid and gas, and I can release and ignite them. My skin is also naturally more fireproof.”
I was still staring in shock at his hands where the flame had been. I nodded slowly. “Ok,” is all I can manage.
The 18 year old points to the 15 year old. “This is Bonnie. Biologically augmented nano n___ intervention environment. Or Bonnie for short. A bunch of nanobots in her body can alter her body physically to overcome most challenges. Increased strength, intelligence, seeing in various spectrums, water breathing anything.”
“Augmented doesn’t start with an O.”
Bonnie gives a shrug. “I didn’t know that when I chose the name, I thought it did, due to the ‘or’ sound.”
The 14 year old steps forward. “The names Ex, my brain is quantumly linked with a quantum computer. If we were in a film, I’d be the tech guy. Super smart, super fast thinking, can use the computer to hack any device.”
I nod. You’d expect me to be even more surprised, but there’s only so much surprise one man can have, and then it just reaches blind acceptance. “And how’d you get the name Ex?”
“The scientists always said that I was simply a part of the computer, an extension of it, so they,” he pointed to the other kids, “started calling me Ex.” Finally I turn to the 12 year old girl. “And you sweetie?”
She looked to the other kids before standing straight and saying “I’m violet and I can change what I look like.” Her hair then changed from pink and blue to bright red and then to blond, looking just like my own. She smiled at me with crooked teeth and I smiled back.
“Oh that was wonderful. And how’d you get your name?”
“My favourite colour is violet.” Her skin then changed to match that colour.
Turning towards the 18 year old I asked, “didn’t catch your name, what is it?”
“Blaze,” he answered.
I nodded, the reason seemed obvious.
I made them a simple lunch, cooking up the rest of the soup before giving them juice and brownies for pudding.
“If you’re running from the government, you can’t stay here long.” They nodded solemnly, except for violet who just looked disappointed. “I can get you food, clothes that’ll stick out less and transport. I can also give you some money to keep you going.
“We couldn’t ask you to do that, that would be so much.”
“I got £24 million from donating my DNA. Money that I planned to pass down to my kids and their kids. Far as I’m concerned, that money’s just as much yours as it is mine.”
And so, without giving them room to refuse, I bought a second hand car that someone was selling on the street, a couple months worth of imperishable food, new clothes and then gave them £10,000 and the best tips and tricks to save money I know. And with that they hugged me goodbye and left.
Barely two days later, two black trucks appeared outside my door and a team of troops emerged. The almost pounded my door down before I answered, as my wife kept our children back.
“What do you want?” I asked.
“Your children, where are they?!”
“What do you want with my children? What’ve they done? They’re good kids! Go to school!-“
“Not those kids!”
I furrowed my eyebrows. “I don’t have any other kids.”
“We know they visited you! Where did they go?!”
“I don’t know what you’re talking about! I don’t have any other kids! I haven’t even had another partner!”
A woman in a black suit walked up to the door, commanding the soldiers to stand down. “We know you know, we tracked them here.”
“What kids are you talking about?” I repeated, playing my best furiously confused civilian.
“Answer our questions or we’ll take these kids instead.”
I growled and glared at them with the fury I’d never felt before. “Do not touch my kids. Any of them. I don’t know where they went, I wasn’t stupid enough to ask. There’s nothing I can tell you that can help.” The woman held my gaze for a moment before nodding.
“He’s telling the truth.”
“And before you attempt to arrest me to lure those children you experimented on to turn into soldiers, this is being recorded and, if I don’t stop it, it will automatically be uploaded to the internet.” I warned. We held each others’ gaze for half a minute at least before she backed down.
“Move out. They aren’t here.” I slammed the front door and collapsed to the ground, shaking from the adrenaline.My family ran up to me and we embraced.
My kids will be fine, I have confidence in them. That’s what I tell myself every night before I go to sleep.
story_a:
The knock at the door was so sudden and forceful that it rattled the half-empty coffee cup on my desk. I had just been about to take a sip when the sound startled me, causing a small splash of lukewarm liquid to spill over the rim. I set the cup down and wiped my hand on my jeans, irritation mingling with curiosity. Who could be banging on my door this early in the morning?
I shuffled to the door, my mind still foggy from sleep. As I opened it, I was greeted by a sight that took a moment to process: five teenagers stood on my porch, each one looking like they’d stepped out of a comic book. There was a girl with hair that seemed to shimmer like molten gold, a boy whose eyes glowed an eerie shade of blue, and another whose skin had a metallic sheen. The two on the end were equally striking—one with a pair of wings folded neatly against his back, and the other with flames dancing along her fingertips.
"Um, can I help you?" I asked, my voice cracking slightly.
The girl with the shimmering hair stepped forward. "Are you John Miller?"
"Yeah, that's me." I frowned, glancing from one teenager to the next. "Who are you?"
"We're your children," she said simply, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. "Or, more accurately, your genetic offspring."
My brain screeched to a halt. I could almost hear the gears grinding. Years ago, I had sold my genetic material to a secret organization for an obscene amount of money—thirty million dollars, to be exact. At the time, it seemed like a no-brainer. I was a struggling grad student with a mountain of debt and no real prospects. The organization, shrouded in mystery and promising confidentiality, had seemed like a godsend.
"Wait, what?" I finally managed to sputter. "You’re saying you're...?"
"Your children," the boy with the glowing eyes repeated, his voice patient but firm. "Created using your genetic material."
I blinked, trying to wrap my head around the bombshell that had just been dropped in my lap. "How is this even possible? And why are you here?"
"It's a long story," the girl said, her golden hair catching the morning light and making her look almost ethereal. "Can we come in?"
I hesitated for a moment, then stepped aside, gesturing for them to enter. They filed in, each one more surreal than the last. I led them to the living room, where they arranged themselves on the couch and armchairs, looking oddly out of place in my modest, cluttered home.
"Alright," I said, taking a seat opposite them. "Start from the beginning."
The girl, who seemed to be the spokesperson for the group, took a deep breath. "Our names are Lana, Max, Jace, Emily, and Ethan. We were created by a secret organization called GenTech. They used your genetic material, along with some... enhancements, to give us our abilities."
"Abilities?" I echoed, glancing at the flames still flickering around Emily's fingers.
"Yes," Lana confirmed. "Each of us has unique powers. I can manipulate light. Max has telekinesis. Jace can control metal. Emily controls fire, and Ethan has wings."
I rubbed my temples, feeling a headache coming on. "And why are you here now?"
"We escaped," Jace said, his metallic skin glinting in the light. "GenTech was using us for experiments, training us to be weapons. We couldn't take it anymore."
"So you came to find me?" I asked, still struggling to process everything.
"You're our father," Max said simply. "We thought you might be able to help us."
I leaned back in my chair, letting out a long breath. This was insane. Absolutely insane. But as I looked at the five teenagers in front of me, I couldn't help but feel a strange sense of responsibility. I had unknowingly played a part in their creation, and now they were here, asking for my help.
"What do you need from me?" I asked, my voice quieter now.
"Protection," Lana said. "A place to hide, at least for a while. We need to figure out our next move, and we can't do that if we're constantly running."
I nodded slowly. "Alright. You can stay here for now. But we need to be careful. If this organization is as powerful as you say, they won't give up easily."
"Thank you," Emily said, her flames extinguishing as she gave me a grateful smile.
Over the next few days, my quiet, uneventful life was turned upside down. The teenagers—my children—settled into my home, filling it with an energy and chaos that I hadn't realized I missed. We spent hours talking, getting to know each other, and they shared stories of their lives at GenTech. It was clear that they had been through a lot, and I couldn't help but feel a growing sense of protectiveness towards them.
Lana, the natural leader, had a calm and steady presence. Max, with his telekinesis, was quiet but thoughtful, always observing and analyzing. Jace, the metal manipulator, was brash and confident, often clashing with Max's more reserved nature. Emily, the fire wielder, was energetic and impulsive, her emotions often flaring as brightly as her flames. And Ethan, the winged boy, was gentle and kind, always ready to offer a comforting word or a helping hand.
As the days turned into weeks, we fell into a routine. I taught them what I could about living a normal life, and they shared their abilities with me, demonstrating the incredible things they could do. It was both awe-inspiring and terrifying to see the extent of their powers.
But the shadow of GenTech loomed over us. We knew it was only a matter of time before they came looking for their prized creations.
One evening, as we sat around the dinner table, a sense of unease settled over us. The air felt charged, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was about to happen. My suspicions were confirmed when there was a loud crash from the front of the house.
"They've found us," Max said, his eyes glowing with a fierce determination.
"Everyone, get ready," Lana commanded, her voice steady even as her hair began to shimmer with an intense light.
The next few moments were a blur. GenTech agents swarmed the house, their dark uniforms and high-tech weapons a stark contrast to the cozy interior. The teenagers sprang into action, their powers on full display as they fought to protect themselves and each other.
Lana's light beams cut through the darkness, blinding the agents and creating barriers of pure energy. Max used his telekinesis to hurl objects and create shields, while Jace manipulated the metal in the room, bending it to his will. Emily's flames roared to life, creating a wall of fire that kept the agents at bay, and Ethan soared through the air, using his wings to knock them off balance.
I did my best to stay out of the way, watching in awe and terror as my children fought for their lives. It was clear that they had been trained well, but the agents were relentless, and I knew we couldn't hold them off forever.
"John!" Lana called out, her voice cutting through the chaos. "We need to get out of here! Now!"
I nodded, my heart pounding in my chest. "This way!" I shouted, leading them through the house to a hidden exit I had installed years ago. We burst out into the night, the cool air a stark contrast to the heat of the battle inside.
"Where do we go?" Emily asked, her flames flickering uncertainly.
"We'll figure it out," I said, my mind racing. "But we need to keep moving."
As we ran through the darkness, I couldn't help but glance back at the house, now a battleground. It was a painful reminder of the life I had left behind, but as I looked at the teenagers running beside me, I knew that I had made the right choice.
We didn't stop until we reached the edge of town, where we found a small, abandoned cabin. It wasn't much, but it would do for now. We collapsed inside, exhausted but alive.
"What's our next move?" Jace asked, his voice tinged with frustration.
"We need to find a way to take down GenTech," Max said, his eyes still glowing with determination. "They won't stop coming after us."
"Agreed," Lana said, her hair shimmering softly. "But we need to be smart about it. We can't take them on head-on. We need to find their weaknesses, gather allies, and strike when they're least expecting it."
I looked at my children, their faces filled with resolve. They had been through so much, but they hadn't given up. And neither would I.
"We'll do whatever it takes," I said, my voice steady. "We'll bring them down, together."
As we huddled in the small cabin, I couldn't help but feel a sense of hope. We had a long road ahead of us, but for the first time in a long while, I felt like we had a chance. A chance to fight back, to protect each other, and to build a future free from the shadows of our past.
And as I looked at my children, I knew that we would face whatever came our way, together.
story_b:
I never thought about what I did back then. It was just a transaction, nothing more. Thirty million dollars for a few vials of my genetic material, facilitated by a shadowy organization that promised anonymity and discretion. At the time, I was drowning in debt, and that money was my lifeline. But it came with a price I never imagined.
Life had moved on, as it tends to, and I found myself in a small, cluttered apartment on the outskirts of a city that never quite felt like home. My days were filled with the mundane routine of a middle management job, a far cry from the chaotic desperation of my past. I buried the memory of that transaction deep, pretending it never happened.
Then came the knock on my door.
I was halfway through a cup of bitter coffee when the sound echoed through the apartment. I opened the door to find a group of teenagers standing awkwardly in the hallway. They were an odd bunch, a mix of nervous energy and quiet determination, their eyes reflecting a kind of hope that made me uneasy.
"Are you... Mr. Holloway?" one of them asked, a girl with fiery red hair that seemed to flicker like flames.
"Depends who's asking," I replied, leaning against the doorframe, trying to mask my surprise and unease with casual defiance.
"We need to talk," said a tall boy with a serious expression. His eyes seemed to pierce through me, as if he could see everything I was trying to hide.
I was about to shut the door, dismiss them as some elaborate prank, when another girl, smaller and looking even more nervous, stepped forward. "Please, it's important. You're... well, you're kind of our father."
My mind reeled. "You've got to be kidding me. Superpowered kids? This is some kind of joke, right?"
They looked at each other, a silent conversation passing among them. "Can we come in?" the red-haired girl asked, her voice tinged with desperation.
Against my better judgment, I stepped aside. They filed in, bringing with them an air of tension and urgency that filled the room. I watched them, trying to piece together the reality that was unraveling in front of me.
"Okay," I said, crossing my arms. "You've got ten minutes. Explain."
The tall boy, who seemed to be their unofficial leader, took a deep breath. "Years ago, you donated your genetic material to a group called GenTech."
The name hit me like a physical blow, a ghost from my past. "Go on."
"They used it to create us," he continued. "We're part of a... project. An experiment, really. They wanted to see if they could engineer superhumans."
"And it worked," the red-haired girl added. Her hair seemed to dance with an inner light as she spoke, confirming her words. "But it also went wrong. They tried to control us, use us. We escaped."
I sat down heavily, the weight of their story sinking in. "And you came here because...?"
"We need your help," the small girl said quietly. "They're still after us. And if the world finds out about us, it could mean the end of everything we know."
I rubbed my temples, trying to process it all. "I didn't ask for this. I didn't want to be a part of some grand experiment."
"But you are," the tall boy said simply. "And we don't have anywhere else to go."
Their eyes were filled with a mix of fear and hope, and I felt a pang of responsibility I couldn't ignore. I was tired of running from my past, but it seemed to have caught up with me. "Alright," I sighed. "Let's figure this out."
As the night stretched on, they told me more about GenTech and the dark secrets they had uncovered. The organization was more than just a scientific endeavor; it was a political force, manipulating power from the shadows. The teenagers' existence threatened to expose these machinations, and GenTech would stop at nothing to ensure their secrets remained buried.
I listened, feeling the burden of my past decisions settle heavily on my shoulders. I never wanted to be a father, especially not like this. But as they spoke, I saw their desperation, their need for guidance and protection. They weren't just superpowered; they were lost, trying to understand who they were and why they existed.
The next morning, we began to plan. My small apartment felt like a prison compared to the sterile, futuristic labs they described. But it was the best we had. As we worked, I couldn't help but notice their unique abilities, each one a testament to the unnatural circumstances of their creation.
The tall boy, whose name I learned was Jordan, could manipulate the very air around him, forming barriers and weapons with a flick of his wrist. The red-haired girl, Ember, controlled fire, her emotions often sparking flames that danced around her. The small girl, Mia, had a gift for empathy, able to sense and influence the emotions of those around her. There were others, too, each with their own struggles and strengths.
They needed me, but I wasn't sure I could be what they needed. I was just a man who had sold his genetic material for a quick payday, never considering the consequences. But as the days passed, I realized I had to try.
We spent hours piecing together the truth behind GenTech, uncovering hidden agendas and dark secrets. The more we learned, the more tangled the web of deception became. The man in the suit, who they called Dr. Graves, wasn't just a scientist; he was a puppet master, pulling strings we couldn't see.
"Dr. Graves has plans," Jordan said one evening, his voice tense. "He wants to use us to tip the balance of power in the world. If he succeeds, it could be catastrophic."
"We need to find out what they really did to us, and why," Ember added, her eyes blazing with determination.
Our search led us to a nondescript building on the outskirts of the city, a place that seemed ordinary but held secrets beneath its facade. It was a GenTech facility, hidden in plain sight. As we approached, I felt a sense of dread settle over me. This was it. The moment where everything could change.
The teenagers looked to me for guidance, their faith in me both humbling and terrifying. "Alright," I said, my voice steady despite the turmoil inside. "Let's do this."
The facility was a maze of glass and steel, filled with the hum of machines and the cold, clinical smell of antiseptic. We moved through the halls with a quiet urgency, searching for the answers we needed.
As we delved deeper, we encountered resistance. GenTech's security forces were relentless, their determination to protect their secrets evident in every encounter. But the teenagers were formidable, their powers a testament to the unnatural designs of their creators.
In the midst of the chaos, we found the lab where it all began. The room was filled with equipment and documents, evidence of the twisted experiments that had brought these teenagers into existence. It was a stark reminder of the consequences of playing god.
"We need to destroy this," Jordan said, his voice filled with resolve. "We can't let them continue."
I nodded, feeling a sense of purpose I hadn't felt in years. "You're right. It's time to end this."
Together, we dismantled the lab, erasing the evidence of GenTech's experiments. As we worked, I realized that these teenagers were more than just the products of a scientific endeavor. They were individuals, each with their own hopes, dreams, and desires. They deserved a chance to find their own paths, free from the shadow of GenTech.
As we left the facility, I felt a sense of liberation. We had done what we could to stop GenTech, but the fight was far from over. There would be more battles to face, more challenges to overcome. But for the first time, I didn't feel alone. I had a new purpose, a new family to protect.
As we walked into the night, I turned to the teenagers, my determination clear. "I may not have wanted this, but I'll be damned if I let anyone hurt you."
They smiled, a mix of relief and hope in their eyes. It was a moment of unexpected revelation, aligning with the truth I hadn't realized until now. I had found a sense of belonging, a role I never expected to play.
And as we faced the uncertain future, I knew that together, we could defy the odds. We weren't just dealing with superpowers; we were dealing with what it meant to be human. And in that struggle, we found our strength.
The world might never know the truth about GenTech and its twisted ambitions, but we did. And as long as we stood together, we could face whatever came our way.
For the first time in years, I felt a spark of hope. I had made a choice, a choice to fight for something greater than myself. And in that choice, I found a new beginning.

They followed me to the kitchen where I kept microwaving my soup and collapsed into the chair, even the small exertion of standing in the doorway wiping me out with my illness.
“So, why would the American government want to make children with my DNA?”
The kids all moved awkwardly to take different spaces in the kitchen. The 14 year old hopped up on the worktop while the 15 year old started rooting through the cupboards.
“Uh, not exactly.” The 18 year old said. “They wanted to make soldiers.”
“Soldiers?” My blood ran cold at the thought. “And why would I be the ‘perfect candidate?”
“No physical conditions of any kind, you were a ‘blank slate’.” I wasn’t sure how to feel about that, was it a compliment? But that wasn’t important at the moment.
I scowled. “And you’re their ‘soldiers’. Children.”
The 18 year old nodded, holding out his hand a conjuring a small flame in it. I almost fell out of my chair in shock as the flame appeared. The 15 year old slapped the 18 year old, who looked sheepish.
“Way to ease him into it,” she told him off.
I pointed to the flame. “How the Heck did you do that?!”
The flame vanished as the 18 year old held his hands up placatingly. “The government wanted more than soldier, they wanted super soldiers. So the experimented with your DNA. I was their first success. My body naturally produces several flammable substances, liquid and gas, and I can release and ignite them. My skin is also naturally more fireproof.”
I was still staring in shock at his hands where the flame had been. I nodded slowly. “Ok,” is all I can manage.
The 18 year old points to the 15 year old. “This is Bonnie. Biologically augmented nano n___ intervention environment. Or Bonnie for short. A bunch of nanobots in her body can alter her body physically to overcome most challenges. Increased strength, intelligence, seeing in various spectrums, water breathing anything.”
“Augmented doesn’t start with an O.”
Bonnie gives a shrug. “I didn’t know that when I chose the name, I thought it did, due to the ‘or’ sound.”
The 14 year old steps forward. “The names Ex, my brain is quantumly linked with a quantum computer. If we were in a film, I’d be the tech guy. Super smart, super fast thinking, can use the computer to hack any device.”
I nod. You’d expect me to be even more surprised, but there’s only so much surprise one man can have, and then it just reaches blind acceptance. “And how’d you get the name Ex?”
“The scientists always said that I was simply a part of the computer, an extension of it, so they,” he pointed to the other kids, “started calling me Ex.” Finally I turn to the 12 year old girl. “And you sweetie?”
She looked to the other kids before standing straight and saying “I’m violet and I can change what I look like.” Her hair then changed from pink and blue to bright red and then to blond, looking just like my own. She smiled at me with crooked teeth and I smiled back.
“Oh that was wonderful. And how’d you get your name?”
“My favourite colour is violet.” Her skin then changed to match that colour.
Turning towards the 18 year old I asked, “didn’t catch your name, what is it?”
“Blaze,” he answered.
I nodded, the reason seemed obvious.
I made them a simple lunch, cooking up the rest of the soup before giving them juice and brownies for pudding.
“If you’re running from the government, you can’t stay here long.” They nodded solemnly, except for violet who just looked disappointed. “I can get you food, clothes that’ll stick out less and transport. I can also give you some money to keep you going.
“We couldn’t ask you to do that, that would be so much.”
“I got £24 million from donating my DNA. Money that I planned to pass down to my kids and their kids. Far as I’m concerned, that money’s just as much yours as it is mine.”
And so, without giving them room to refuse, I bought a second hand car that someone was selling on the street, a couple months worth of imperishable food, new clothes and then gave them £10,000 and the best tips and tricks to save money I know. And with that they hugged me goodbye and left.
Barely two days later, two black trucks appeared outside my door and a team of troops emerged. The almost pounded my door down before I answered, as my wife kept our children back.
“What do you want?” I asked.
“Your children, where are they?!”
“What do you want with my children? What’ve they done? They’re good kids! Go to school!-“
“Not those kids!”
I furrowed my eyebrows. “I don’t have any other kids.”
“We know they visited you! Where did they go?!”
“I don’t know what you’re talking about! I don’t have any other kids! I haven’t even had another partner!”
A woman in a black suit walked up to the door, commanding the soldiers to stand down. “We know you know, we tracked them here.”
“What kids are you talking about?” I repeated, playing my best furiously confused civilian.
“Answer our questions or we’ll take these kids instead.”
I growled and glared at them with the fury I’d never felt before. “Do not touch my kids. Any of them. I don’t know where they went, I wasn’t stupid enough to ask. There’s nothing I can tell you that can help.” The woman held my gaze for a moment before nodding.
“He’s telling the truth.”
“And before you attempt to arrest me to lure those children you experimented on to turn into soldiers, this is being recorded and, if I don’t stop it, it will automatically be uploaded to the internet.” I warned. We held each others’ gaze for half a minute at least before she backed down.
“Move out. They aren’t here.” I slammed the front door and collapsed to the ground, shaking from the adrenaline.My family ran up to me and we embraced.
My kids will be fine, I have confidence in them. That’s what I tell myself every night before I go to sleep.
story_a:
The knock at the door was so sudden and forceful that it rattled the half-empty coffee cup on my desk. I had just been about to take a sip when the sound startled me, causing a small splash of lukewarm liquid to spill over the rim. I set the cup down and wiped my hand on my jeans, irritation mingling with curiosity. Who could be banging on my door this early in the morning?
I shuffled to the door, my mind still foggy from sleep. As I opened it, I was greeted by a sight that took a moment to process: five teenagers stood on my porch, each one looking like they’d stepped out of a comic book. There was a girl with hair that seemed to shimmer like molten gold, a boy whose eyes glowed an eerie shade of blue, and another whose skin had a metallic sheen. The two on the end were equally striking—one with a pair of wings folded neatly against his back, and the other with flames dancing along her fingertips.
"Um, can I help you?" I asked, my voice cracking slightly.
The girl with the shimmering hair stepped forward. "Are you John Miller?"
"Yeah, that's me." I frowned, glancing from one teenager to the next. "Who are you?"
"We're your children," she said simply, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. "Or, more accurately, your genetic offspring."
My brain screeched to a halt. I could almost hear the gears grinding. Years ago, I had sold my genetic material to a secret organization for an obscene amount of money—thirty million dollars, to be exact. At the time, it seemed like a no-brainer. I was a struggling grad student with a mountain of debt and no real prospects. The organization, shrouded in mystery and promising confidentiality, had seemed like a godsend.
"Wait, what?" I finally managed to sputter. "You’re saying you're...?"
"Your children," the boy with the glowing eyes repeated, his voice patient but firm. "Created using your genetic material."
I blinked, trying to wrap my head around the bombshell that had just been dropped in my lap. "How is this even possible? And why are you here?"
"It's a long story," the girl said, her golden hair catching the morning light and making her look almost ethereal. "Can we come in?"
I hesitated for a moment, then stepped aside, gesturing for them to enter. They filed in, each one more surreal than the last. I led them to the living room, where they arranged themselves on the couch and armchairs, looking oddly out of place in my modest, cluttered home.
"Alright," I said, taking a seat opposite them. "Start from the beginning."
The girl, who seemed to be the spokesperson for the group, took a deep breath. "Our names are Lana, Max, Jace, Emily, and Ethan. We were created by a secret organization called GenTech. They used your genetic material, along with some... enhancements, to give us our abilities."
"Abilities?" I echoed, glancing at the flames still flickering around Emily's fingers.
"Yes," Lana confirmed. "Each of us has unique powers. I can manipulate light. Max has telekinesis. Jace can control metal. Emily controls fire, and Ethan has wings."
I rubbed my temples, feeling a headache coming on. "And why are you here now?"
"We escaped," Jace said, his metallic skin glinting in the light. "GenTech was using us for experiments, training us to be weapons. We couldn't take it anymore."
"So you came to find me?" I asked, still struggling to process everything.
"You're our father," Max said simply. "We thought you might be able to help us."
I leaned back in my chair, letting out a long breath. This was insane. Absolutely insane. But as I looked at the five teenagers in front of me, I couldn't help but feel a strange sense of responsibility. I had unknowingly played a part in their creation, and now they were here, asking for my help.
"What do you need from me?" I asked, my voice quieter now.
"Protection," Lana said. "A place to hide, at least for a while. We need to figure out our next move, and we can't do that if we're constantly running."
I nodded slowly. "Alright. You can stay here for now. But we need to be careful. If this organization is as powerful as you say, they won't give up easily."
"Thank you," Emily said, her flames extinguishing as she gave me a grateful smile.
Over the next few days, my quiet, uneventful life was turned upside down. The teenagers—my children—settled into my home, filling it with an energy and chaos that I hadn't realized I missed. We spent hours talking, getting to know each other, and they shared stories of their lives at GenTech. It was clear that they had been through a lot, and I couldn't help but feel a growing sense of protectiveness towards them.
Lana, the natural leader, had a calm and steady presence. Max, with his telekinesis, was quiet but thoughtful, always observing and analyzing. Jace, the metal manipulator, was brash and confident, often clashing with Max's more reserved nature. Emily, the fire wielder, was energetic and impulsive, her emotions often flaring as brightly as her flames. And Ethan, the winged boy, was gentle and kind, always ready to offer a comforting word or a helping hand.
As the days turned into weeks, we fell into a routine. I taught them what I could about living a normal life, and they shared their abilities with me, demonstrating the incredible things they could do. It was both awe-inspiring and terrifying to see the extent of their powers.
But the shadow of GenTech loomed over us. We knew it was only a matter of time before they came looking for their prized creations.
One evening, as we sat around the dinner table, a sense of unease settled over us. The air felt charged, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was about to happen. My suspicions were confirmed when there was a loud crash from the front of the house.
"They've found us," Max said, his eyes glowing with a fierce determination.
"Everyone, get ready," Lana commanded, her voice steady even as her hair began to shimmer with an intense light.
The next few moments were a blur. GenTech agents swarmed the house, their dark uniforms and high-tech weapons a stark contrast to the cozy interior. The teenagers sprang into action, their powers on full display as they fought to protect themselves and each other.
Lana's light beams cut through the darkness, blinding the agents and creating barriers of pure energy. Max used his telekinesis to hurl objects and create shields, while Jace manipulated the metal in the room, bending it to his will. Emily's flames roared to life, creating a wall of fire that kept the agents at bay, and Ethan soared through the air, using his wings to knock them off balance.
I did my best to stay out of the way, watching in awe and terror as my children fought for their lives. It was clear that they had been trained well, but the agents were relentless, and I knew we couldn't hold them off forever.
"John!" Lana called out, her voice cutting through the chaos. "We need to get out of here! Now!"
I nodded, my heart pounding in my chest. "This way!" I shouted, leading them through the house to a hidden exit I had installed years ago. We burst out into the night, the cool air a stark contrast to the heat of the battle inside.
"Where do we go?" Emily asked, her flames flickering uncertainly.
"We'll figure it out," I said, my mind racing. "But we need to keep moving."
As we ran through the darkness, I couldn't help but glance back at the house, now a battleground. It was a painful reminder of the life I had left behind, but as I looked at the teenagers running beside me, I knew that I had made the right choice.
We didn't stop until we reached the edge of town, where we found a small, abandoned cabin. It wasn't much, but it would do for now. We collapsed inside, exhausted but alive.
"What's our next move?" Jace asked, his voice tinged with frustration.
"We need to find a way to take down GenTech," Max said, his eyes still glowing with determination. "They won't stop coming after us."
"Agreed," Lana said, her hair shimmering softly. "But we need to be smart about it. We can't take them on head-on. We need to find their weaknesses, gather allies, and strike when they're least expecting it."
I looked at my children, their faces filled with resolve. They had been through so much, but they hadn't given up. And neither would I.
"We'll do whatever it takes," I said, my voice steady. "We'll bring them down, together."
As we huddled in the small cabin, I couldn't help but feel a sense of hope. We had a long road ahead of us, but for the first time in a long while, I felt like we had a chance. A chance to fight back, to protect each other, and to build a future free from the shadows of our past.
And as I looked at my children, I knew that we would face whatever came our way, together.
story_b:
I opened the door, expecting a delivery, but instead, I was met with a group of teenagers, each displaying a unique power. One was levitating, another had glowing eyes, and the third was holding a small fireball in their hand. For a moment, I was convinced I was having some bizarre hallucination. Maybe I'd accidentally inhaled something from the old paint cans in the garage.
“Hello, Father,” said the boy who was floating a few inches off my porch. He had a grin that was both mischievous and endearing, as though he’d just pulled off a great prank. I blinked, trying to process the scene before me. “Father? Me? There must be some mistake.”
The girl with the glowing eyes rolled them dramatically. “Yeah, we get that a lot,” she said, her voice laced with the kind of sarcasm only teenagers could muster. “But, trust us, there’s no mistake.”
The third kid, a girl with a flaming sphere hovering just above her palm, gave me an apologetic smile. “We didn’t mean to scare you. It’s just… well, you’re kind of our dad.”
I stepped back into the hallway, trying to wrap my head around this unlikely reality. “So, let me get this straight,” I said, gesturing for them to come inside. “You’re saying you’re my kids, and you have… powers?”
The levitating boy, who introduced himself as Max, nodded enthusiastically as he floated through the door. “Yep! I can levitate. Lily there can see in the dark and more. And Emma, well, she’s got a bit of a fiery touch.”
Emma nodded, extinguishing the fireball with a flick of her wrist. “We might have more powers, but these are the ones we know for sure.”
As they settled into my living room, I took a moment to observe them more closely. There was something familiar about each of them, a sense of déjà vu that tugged at the edges of my memory. But it wasn’t until Lily, the girl with the glowing eyes, started rifling through my mail that it hit me.
Years ago, in a moment of desperation and maybe a bit of reckless abandon, I had agreed to donate my genetic material to a shadowy organization in exchange for $30 million. I’d never thought about the consequences of that decision. I’d been assured it was all very confidential, very secure. And now here they were, the living, breathing—levitating—proof of my past decision standing in my living room.
“I never thought my decision would lead to this,” I muttered under my breath. “A group of superpowered kids looking to me for answers.”
Max floated over to my old recliner, touching down on the floor with a thump. “You’re probably wondering how we found you,” he said, as if reading my mind. “It took some time, but we pieced it together. We’ve been… well, looking for you.”
“Looking for me? Why?”
Lily tossed a letter back onto the coffee table. “Because we need your help. The organization is looking for us, and they’re not happy we’ve gone off the grid.”
I felt a cold shiver run down my spine. “What do you mean, ‘off the grid’? What exactly are they planning?”
Emma leaned forward, her eyes earnest. “They want to control us, use us for their own purposes. But we’re more than just experiments. We’re people.”
I rubbed my temples, feeling the weight of their words pressing down on me. “Okay, okay. Let’s start at the beginning. Why me? Why now?”
Max shrugged, his grin fading into something more serious. “We’ve been on the run for a while, but we’re tired. We need someone who can help us figure out who we really are.”
“And you think that’s me?”
Lily nodded. “You might not have all the answers, but you’re the closest thing to family we have.”
I leaned back in my chair, trying to come to terms with the fact that these kids, these extraordinary kids, were somehow my responsibility. “Alright,” I sighed, feeling the first stirrings of an unfamiliar protectiveness. “Let’s figure this out together.”
As the initial shock wore off, I found myself strangely at ease with them in my home. My small apartment, once a haven of solitude, was now filled with the chaotic energy of teenagers testing their powers. The air crackled with energy as Max floated effortlessly, his laughter echoing in the small space.
Lily, with her intense gaze, seemed to see through everything, including my walls of self-deception. Emma, meanwhile, practiced her pyrotechnics with a cautious focus, ensuring she didn’t accidentally set anything else ablaze.
“Okay, ground rules,” I said, trying to assert some semblance of authority. “No setting things on fire, no levitating things that shouldn’t be levitated, and please, no looking through my mail. It’s mostly bills and junk anyway.”
Max snorted, clearly unbothered by my attempt at house rules. “Got it, Dad. No fun allowed.”
I shot him a look. “I’m serious. You kids might have powers, but you’re still… well, kids. And I’m responsible for you now.”
Emma snickered. “Does that mean we get an allowance?”
I chuckled despite myself. “We’ll see. But first, we need to figure out how to keep you safe from this organization.”
Lily’s expression turned somber. “They’ll come looking for us. They always do.”
I nodded, trying to think strategically. “We need to stay a step ahead. Maybe if we find out more about their plans, we can expose them or at least keep them off your trail.”
Max floated over to me, his eyes earnest. “We trust you, Dad. We know this is a lot, but we’re glad we found you.”
Something shifted inside me at his words. Despite the absurdity of it all, I felt an overwhelming urge to protect them, to be the father they seemed to think I could be. “Alright,” I said, determination settling in my chest. “Let’s figure out a plan.”
Over the following weeks, my life transformed in ways I could never have anticipated. My apartment became a headquarters of sorts, a place where the kids could hone their powers while we devised ways to keep them safe. I found myself playing roles I never thought I’d have: mentor, strategist, and, most dauntingly, father.
As we dug deeper into the organization’s secrets, it became clear that their plans were more insidious than any of us had imagined. They had been engineering superpowered beings for their own gain, intending to unleash them on a world unprepared for their abilities. The kids were just the beginning.
Through it all, I marveled at their resilience and spirit. Max, with his buoyant personality, kept us all grounded, his laughter a constant reminder that we were more than just the circumstances that had brought us together. Lily’s quiet strength and piercing gaze kept us focused, her insights invaluable as we pieced together the organization’s plans. Emma’s fiery determination inspired us to keep pushing forward, her courage infectious.
In the midst of our planning and strategizing, we found moments of unexpected joy. I discovered that Max had a knack for cooking, his culinary experiments often resulting in surprisingly delicious meals. Lily was a voracious reader, her love of books rivaling my own. Emma, despite her fiery nature, had a gentle soul, often tending to the small garden I had neglected for years.
Our bond deepened, and I found myself embracing my role as their protector and guide. I was just an ordinary guy with an extraordinary past mistake, but as I watched them grow and learn, I realized I couldn’t just walk away. They were my family now, and I would do whatever it took to keep them safe.
As our investigation neared its climax, we stumbled upon a crucial piece of information: the location of the organization’s main facility. It was a sprawling complex hidden in the mountains, a fortress of secrecy and shadows. We knew it was a risk, but we had to act. We couldn’t let them continue their experiments, not when so many lives were at stake.
The night of the operation, tension hung heavy in the air. The kids were ready, their powers honed and focused, their determination unwavering. I was proud of them, of how far they’d come, but I couldn’t shake the fear that gnawed at my insides.
“Are you sure about this?” I asked them, my voice barely above a whisper.
Max nodded, his usual levity replaced by a steely resolve. “We have to do this, Dad. It’s the only way to stop them.”
Lily placed a hand on my shoulder, her eyes glowing softly in the dim light. “We’re ready. We can do this.”
Emma gave me a reassuring smile, her fingers igniting with a controlled flame. “Together, we’ve got this.”
With a deep breath, I nodded, steeling myself for what was to come. “Alright. Let’s go.”
The operation unfolded with a precision I hadn’t dared hope for. Max’s levitation allowed us to bypass security measures, while Lily’s keen eyes guided us through the labyrinthine corridors. Emma’s flames provided both light and a formidable deterrent against any threats we encountered.
As we reached the heart of the facility, I couldn’t help but feel a sense of awe at the kids’ abilities and their unwavering courage. They were extraordinary, not just because of their powers, but because of their strength and resilience in the face of adversity.
We confronted the organization’s leaders, exposing their plans and gathering the evidence we needed to bring them down. It was a victory hard-won, a testament to the power of determination and the bonds we had forged.
In the aftermath, as we stood outside the facility, watching as authorities moved in to secure the site, I felt a profound sense of relief and gratitude. We had done it. We had stopped them.
Turning to the kids, I smiled, pride swelling in my chest. “You did it. We did it.”
Max grinned, his feet hovering just above the ground. “We couldn’t have done it without you, Dad.”
Lily nodded, her eyes reflecting a warmth I hadn’t seen before. “Thank you for believing in us.”
Emma gave me a hug, her touch warm and reassuring. “We’re a family now, right?”
“Yeah,” I said, my voice thick with emotion. “We’re a family.”
In that moment, I realized that my past mistake had led me to something far greater than I could have ever imagined. These kids, with their extraordinary abilities and boundless potential, were my legacy. And I would stand by them, guide them, and protect them, no matter what the future held.
Together, we would face whatever challenges came our way. Together, we would build a new future, one filled with hope, understanding, and the unbreakable bonds of family.
