“I got £24 million from donating my DNA. Money that I planned to pass down to my kids and their kids. Far as I’m concerned, that money’s just as much yours as it is mine.”
And so, without giving them room to refuse, I bought a second hand car that someone was selling on the street, a couple months worth of imperishable food, new clothes and then gave them £10,000 and the best tips and tricks to save money I know. And with that they hugged me goodbye and left.
Barely two days later, two black trucks appeared outside my door and a team of troops emerged. The almost pounded my door down before I answered, as my wife kept our children back.
“What do you want?” I asked.
“Your children, where are they?!”
“What do you want with my children? What’ve they done? They’re good kids! Go to school!-“
“Not those kids!”
I furrowed my eyebrows. “I don’t have any other kids.”
“We know they visited you! Where did they go?!”
“I don’t know what you’re talking about! I don’t have any other kids! I haven’t even had another partner!”
A woman in a black suit walked up to the door, commanding the soldiers to stand down. “We know you know, we tracked them here.”
“What kids are you talking about?” I repeated, playing my best furiously confused civilian.
“Answer our questions or we’ll take these kids instead.”
I growled and glared at them with the fury I’d never felt before. “Do not touch my kids. Any of them. I don’t know where they went, I wasn’t stupid enough to ask. There’s nothing I can tell you that can help.” The woman held my gaze for a moment before nodding.
“He’s telling the truth.”
“And before you attempt to arrest me to lure those children you experimented on to turn into soldiers, this is being recorded and, if I don’t stop it, it will automatically be uploaded to the internet.” I warned. We held each others’ gaze for half a minute at least before she backed down.
“Move out. They aren’t here.” I slammed the front door and collapsed to the ground, shaking from the adrenaline.My family ran up to me and we embraced.
My kids will be fine, I have confidence in them. That’s what I tell myself every night before I go to sleep.
story_a:
The knock at the door was so sudden and forceful that it rattled the half-empty coffee cup on my desk. I had just been about to take a sip when the sound startled me, causing a small splash of lukewarm liquid to spill over the rim. I set the cup down and wiped my hand on my jeans, irritation mingling with curiosity. Who could be banging on my door this early in the morning?
I shuffled to the door, my mind still foggy from sleep. As I opened it, I was greeted by a sight that took a moment to process: five teenagers stood on my porch, each one looking like they’d stepped out of a comic book. There was a girl with hair that seemed to shimmer like molten gold, a boy whose eyes glowed an eerie shade of blue, and another whose skin had a metallic sheen. The two on the end were equally striking—one with a pair of wings folded neatly against his back, and the other with flames dancing along her fingertips.
"Um, can I help you?" I asked, my voice cracking slightly.
The girl with the shimmering hair stepped forward. "Are you John Miller?"
"Yeah, that's me." I frowned, glancing from one teenager to the next. "Who are you?"
"We're your children," she said simply, as if it were the most natural thing in the world. "Or, more accurately, your genetic offspring."
My brain screeched to a halt. I could almost hear the gears grinding. Years ago, I had sold my genetic material to a secret organization for an obscene amount of money—thirty million dollars, to be exact. At the time, it seemed like a no-brainer. I was a struggling grad student with a mountain of debt and no real prospects. The organization, shrouded in mystery and promising confidentiality, had seemed like a godsend.
"Wait, what?" I finally managed to sputter. "You’re saying you're...?"
"Your children," the boy with the glowing eyes repeated, his voice patient but firm. "Created using your genetic material."
I blinked, trying to wrap my head around the bombshell that had just been dropped in my lap. "How is this even possible? And why are you here?"
"It's a long story," the girl said, her golden hair catching the morning light and making her look almost ethereal. "Can we come in?"
I hesitated for a moment, then stepped aside, gesturing for them to enter. They filed in, each one more surreal than the last. I led them to the living room, where they arranged themselves on the couch and armchairs, looking oddly out of place in my modest, cluttered home.
"Alright," I said, taking a seat opposite them. "Start from the beginning."
The girl, who seemed to be the spokesperson for the group, took a deep breath. "Our names are Lana, Max, Jace, Emily, and Ethan. We were created by a secret organization called GenTech. They used your genetic material, along with some... enhancements, to give us our abilities."
"Abilities?" I echoed, glancing at the flames still flickering around Emily's fingers.
"Yes," Lana confirmed. "Each of us has unique powers. I can manipulate light. Max has telekinesis. Jace can control metal. Emily controls fire, and Ethan has wings."
I rubbed my temples, feeling a headache coming on. "And why are you here now?"
"We escaped," Jace said, his metallic skin glinting in the light. "GenTech was using us for experiments, training us to be weapons. We couldn't take it anymore."
"So you came to find me?" I asked, still struggling to process everything.
"You're our father," Max said simply. "We thought you might be able to help us."
I leaned back in my chair, letting out a long breath. This was insane. Absolutely insane. But as I looked at the five teenagers in front of me, I couldn't help but feel a strange sense of responsibility. I had unknowingly played a part in their creation, and now they were here, asking for my help.
"What do you need from me?" I asked, my voice quieter now.
"Protection," Lana said. "A place to hide, at least for a while. We need to figure out our next move, and we can't do that if we're constantly running."
I nodded slowly. "Alright. You can stay here for now. But we need to be careful. If this organization is as powerful as you say, they won't give up easily."
"Thank you," Emily said, her flames extinguishing as she gave me a grateful smile.
Over the next few days, my quiet, uneventful life was turned upside down. The teenagers—my children—settled into my home, filling it with an energy and chaos that I hadn't realized I missed. We spent hours talking, getting to know each other, and they shared stories of their lives at GenTech. It was clear that they had been through a lot, and I couldn't help but feel a growing sense of protectiveness towards them.
Lana, the natural leader, had a calm and steady presence. Max, with his telekinesis, was quiet but thoughtful, always observing and analyzing. Jace, the metal manipulator, was brash and confident, often clashing with Max's more reserved nature. Emily, the fire wielder, was energetic and impulsive, her emotions often flaring as brightly as her flames. And Ethan, the winged boy, was gentle and kind, always ready to offer a comforting word or a helping hand.
As the days turned into weeks, we fell into a routine. I taught them what I could about living a normal life, and they shared their abilities with me, demonstrating the incredible things they could do. It was both awe-inspiring and terrifying to see the extent of their powers.
But the shadow of GenTech loomed over us. We knew it was only a matter of time before they came looking for their prized creations.
One evening, as we sat around the dinner table, a sense of unease settled over us. The air felt charged, and I couldn't shake the feeling that something was about to happen. My suspicions were confirmed when there was a loud crash from the front of the house.
"They've found us," Max said, his eyes glowing with a fierce determination.
"Everyone, get ready," Lana commanded, her voice steady even as her hair began to shimmer with an intense light.
The next few moments were a blur. GenTech agents swarmed the house, their dark uniforms and high-tech weapons a stark contrast to the cozy interior. The teenagers sprang into action, their powers on full display as they fought to protect themselves and each other.
Lana's light beams cut through the darkness, blinding the agents and creating barriers of pure energy. Max used his telekinesis to hurl objects and create shields, while Jace manipulated the metal in the room, bending it to his will. Emily's flames roared to life, creating a wall of fire that kept the agents at bay, and Ethan soared through the air, using his wings to knock them off balance.
I did my best to stay out of the way, watching in awe and terror as my children fought for their lives. It was clear that they had been trained well, but the agents were relentless, and I knew we couldn't hold them off forever.
"John!" Lana called out, her voice cutting through the chaos. "We need to get out of here! Now!"
I nodded, my heart pounding in my chest. "This way!" I shouted, leading them through the house to a hidden exit I had installed years ago. We burst out into the night, the cool air a stark contrast to the heat of the battle inside.
"Where do we go?" Emily asked, her flames flickering uncertainly.
"We'll figure it out," I said, my mind racing. "But we need to keep moving."
As we ran through the darkness, I couldn't help but glance back at the house, now a battleground. It was a painful reminder of the life I had left behind, but as I looked at the teenagers running beside me, I knew that I had made the right choice.
We didn't stop until we reached the edge of town, where we found a small, abandoned cabin. It wasn't much, but it would do for now. We collapsed inside, exhausted but alive.
"What's our next move?" Jace asked, his voice tinged with frustration.
"We need to find a way to take down GenTech," Max said, his eyes still glowing with determination. "They won't stop coming after us."
"Agreed," Lana said, her hair shimmering softly. "But we need to be smart about it. We can't take them on head-on. We need to find their weaknesses, gather allies, and strike when they're least expecting it."
I looked at my children, their faces filled with resolve. They had been through so much, but they hadn't given up. And neither would I.
"We'll do whatever it takes," I said, my voice steady. "We'll bring them down, together."
As we huddled in the small cabin, I couldn't help but feel a sense of hope. We had a long road ahead of us, but for the first time in a long while, I felt like we had a chance. A chance to fight back, to protect each other, and to build a future free from the shadows of our past.
And as I looked at my children, I knew that we would face whatever came our way, together.
story_b:
The knock on the door was sharp, insistent, and completely unwelcome at 7 a.m. on a Saturday. I blinked bleary-eyed at the clock, groaned, and shuffled my way to the front door, pulling my robe tighter against the morning chill. I was fully prepared to give whoever it was a piece of my mind for disturbing my sacred weekend slumber.
When I swung the door open, however, the words died in my throat. Standing on my porch were five teenagers, each with an aura that screamed 'weird' in a way I couldn’t quite place. The girl in the front, a spitting image of someone I couldn't quite remember, looked me dead in the eye. Her gaze was intense, almost luminous, like she could see right through me.
“Dad?” she said, her voice steady but carrying a note of something that could have been fear or anticipation.
I blinked. “I’m sorry, what?”
“We're your kids,” she clarified, as if that explained everything. “You donated your... genetic material, years ago. And, well, here we are.”
I stood there, gaping like a fish, as the memories flooded back. A clandestine meeting in a sterile, whitewashed lab. A contract thicker than a phone book. And thirty million dollars that had changed my life forever. It was supposed to be anonymous, a one-time thing. I never thought anything would come of it.
But here they were. My kids. Five of them. And each of them, I noticed now, had an almost otherworldly presence about them.
“Can I come in?” the girl asked, gesturing to the others. “We have... a lot to discuss.”
Mechanically, I stepped aside and let them in, my mind whirling with disbelief. They filed into the living room, each of them glancing around like they were analyzing every corner of my modest home. I tried to process this surreal turn of events. I had children. Superpowered children.
“We should introduce ourselves,” the girl suggested, taking charge. She pointed to herself. “I’m Lila. I can manipulate energy fields.” She gestured to a lanky boy with hair that defied gravity. “That’s Jake. He’s got telekinesis.” Jake gave a little wave, a stack of my mail levitating a few inches off the table before settling back down.
Next was a girl with vibrant green eyes and an aura of calm. “Mara. I can heal.” She gave me a shy smile.
Beside her was a boy who looked like he could bench press my car without breaking a sweat. “Rory,” he grunted, flexing muscles that seemed to ripple with power. “Super strength.”
Finally, a girl with hair that seemed to shimmer like a mirage. “I’m Zara. I can phase through things.” To demonstrate, she casually stepped through the arm of my couch, reappearing on the other side with a triumphant grin.
I rubbed my temples, trying to stave off the headache that was forming. “Okay, okay. Let’s say I believe you. Why are you here?”
Lila took a deep breath. “We need your help. There’s a threat coming, something big. And only you can help us stop it.”
“Me?” I couldn’t help the incredulous laugh that escaped. “I’m just a guy who made a questionable decision for a lot of money. What do you expect me to do?”
Jake spoke up, his voice earnest. “You’re more important than you think. The organization that created us, they’re not what they seem. They have plans, dangerous ones, and they’re coming for us.”
My mind raced, a thousand questions battling for dominance. How was I supposed to be a father to these kids, let alone protect them from whatever was coming? I was out of my depth, drowning in a sea of unexpected responsibilities.
“Look, I’m not cut out for this,” I began, but the looks on their faces stopped me. They were counting on me. My kids, who I hadn’t known existed until today, needed me to step up.
As I looked at them, the weight of my past choices settled on my shoulders. I had to do this, not just for them, but for the world they were trying to save. It was time to stop running from the consequences of my actions.
“Okay,” I said finally, my voice firm despite the turmoil inside. “Tell me everything.”
Over the next few hours, they explained how they’d been raised in a secret facility, trained to harness their abilities. The facility was a mix of high-tech labs and training grounds, straight out of a sci-fi movie. But beneath its shiny exterior lurked a darker purpose.
“They want to use us as weapons,” Zara explained, her voice tinged with fear. “We escaped, but they won’t stop until they have us back.”
A cold shiver ran down my spine. This was bigger than I had imagined. The stakes were higher than I’d ever anticipated when I’d signed that contract.
As the sun began to set, painting the room in hues of orange and pink, I knew what I had to do. Leaving my old life behind, I joined them, ready to face whatever challenges lay ahead. It was a sacrifice, but one I was willing to make for my children and the future.
We set out that night, the kids guiding me to a safe house hidden deep in the woods. The air was crisp and filled with the sounds of nature, a stark contrast to the chaos that had erupted in my life. The safe house was a simple cabin, equipped with everything we’d need to plan our next move.
Inside, the atmosphere was tense but hopeful. We gathered around a makeshift table, a map spread out before us. Lila took the lead, outlining the organization’s known facilities and their likely targets.
“We need to hit them where it hurts,” she said, determination etched on her face. “Disrupt their operations and expose their plans to the world.”
As we strategized, I couldn’t help but marvel at these kids. Despite everything they’d been through, they were resilient, determined to fight for their freedom and the safety of others. Their strength inspired me, and I felt a growing sense of responsibility to protect them.
But deep down, I knew that the path ahead would be fraught with danger. We were up against a powerful organization with resources beyond our imagination. The odds were stacked against us, but for the first time in my life, I was ready to face them head-on.
Over the next few days, we trained together, honing their abilities and preparing for the battle ahead. I found myself slipping into the role of a mentor and protector, guiding them as best as I could. Despite the weight of our mission, there were moments of levity and laughter, a newfound sense of family forming between us.
As we bonded, I learned more about their pasts. Each of them had a unique story, shaped by their experiences in the facility. Lila, the natural leader, had always been the one to rally the others, her energy manipulation a constant source of strength. Jake, with his telekinesis, had a mischievous streak, often using his powers to play pranks on the guards. Mara, the healer, was the heart of the group, her gentle nature a balm to their wounds. Rory, with his super strength, was fiercely protective, always putting himself in harm’s way to shield the others. And Zara, with her phasing ability, was the scout, slipping through walls to gather intelligence.
Their stories touched me, and I realized that I wanted to be a part of their lives, to help them find a future beyond the shadow of the organization that had created them.
Finally, the day of the mission arrived. We set out at dawn, our target a remote facility hidden within a mountain range. The journey was arduous, but the kids’ determination never wavered. As we approached the facility, I felt a knot of anxiety tighten in my stomach. This was it—the moment where everything would change.
The facility loomed before us, its steel exterior glinting in the early morning light. We split into teams, each with a specific objective. Lila and Jake would disable the security systems, while Mara and Rory created a diversion. Zara and I would infiltrate the main control room, gathering evidence to expose the organization’s plans.
The operation began smoothly, each of the kids executing their roles with precision and skill. As Zara and I slipped through the facility, my heart pounded in my chest, a mixture of fear and adrenaline driving me forward.
We reached the control room undetected, Zara phasing us through the door. The room was a high-tech command center, screens displaying data and surveillance feeds. As we downloaded the evidence, I couldn’t shake the feeling that something was off. The facility was too quiet, as if they were expecting us.
Suddenly, alarms blared, red lights flashing throughout the room. We’d been discovered. I cursed under my breath, knowing that time was running out.
“Dad, we’ve got company,” Zara said, her voice tense as she scanned the monitors.
I glanced at the screens, seeing guards converging on our location. We needed to move, and fast. “We’ve got what we need. Let’s go.”
Zara nodded, her face set with determination. We retraced our steps, dodging guards and security measures. As we neared the exit, the sound of gunfire echoed through the halls, the kids’ diversion drawing the guards away from our path.
We regrouped outside the facility, the others waiting for us with anxious expressions. “Did you get it?” Lila asked, her eyes searching mine for reassurance.
I nodded, holding up the device containing the evidence. “We did. Let’s get out of here.”
As we made our escape, the facility exploded behind us, the kids’ sabotage leaving nothing but rubble and smoke in its wake. The mission was a success, but the fight was far from over.
Back at the safe house, we reviewed the evidence, our suspicions confirmed. The organization’s plans were more sinister than we’d imagined, their reach extending far beyond what we’d anticipated. But now, armed with the truth, we had a fighting chance.
Over the following weeks, we worked tirelessly to expose the organization, rallying support from allies and spreading the evidence far and wide. The kids’ powers proved invaluable, their abilities turning the tide in our favor.
As the world learned the truth, the organization crumbled, their influence diminishing with each passing day. It was a hard-fought victory, but one that came with a sense of hope and renewal.
In the aftermath, the kids and I settled into a new routine, rebuilding our lives and forging a future together. I’d never imagined that my decision all those years ago would lead to this—a family, a purpose, and a chance to make a difference.
As I watched them grow, I knew that they had given me a gift beyond measure. They’d taught me the true meaning of resilience, of sacrifice, and of love. And in return, I vowed to be the father they deserved, guiding them through the challenges ahead and celebrating every triumph along the way.
Together, we faced the world, ready to embrace whatever came next, united by the bond that had brought us together and the future we were determined to create.

prompt: A man who once assassinated a tyrant wrestles with the decision to kill again when a new, even crueler leader rises to power, knowing the cost of his actions will haunt him forever.
ground_truth:
That spring the premier implemented a series of daring protocols. He was a thin man, sharp dresser. After lunch you’d see him leaving a certain outdoor café erratically, in a party spirit, knocking back the last drops from an elongated champagne flute he’d leave on the low wall by the lane for the waiter to scurry over and collect.
With him would go three hulking curved backs, and sometimes a shaved head on a thick neck would turn, accusing any diners whose eyes still followed the premier. About these thick-necks hung a suggestion of guns concealed beneath expensive jackets worn casually, as if they’d been born thick-necked babies and issued tiny expensive Italian shoes and immediately started chewing gum and being suspicious of the other babies in the nursery while waiting for the premier to come and find them so that the truly useful part of their lives could begin.
The premier’s ethos had left its mark even on the river, which ran now through a changed city where the warmth formerly felt among the people seemed a quaint relic of some earlier, lethargic era during which little brusque progress had been made. Occasionally, the river would cough up a body, having first imbued it with a reptilian cast that made the person the reptile used to be seem retrospectively guilty.
A person wanted to stay clear of it, all of it. Sons were swept into the militia or trucked to a rumored labor camp out beyond the slaughterhouse. Daughters, too, were vanishing—seen slithering into cars, ruined, addicted, smirking.
Distinction of any kind could land one (one’s child, one’s spouse, even one’s horse—a horse was taken for the sins of its owner) in the river. The thing to do was develop an interest in the flower boxes on one’s balcony or keep a record of the stars one saw at night and lose oneself entirely in such things.
Then it was fall and a red car burst into the café, throwing tables around. It seemed to want the premier and it left as soon as it had got him, bucking a few unlucky diners off its back. The thick-necks were now melded into one entity, a woven placemat improbably atop it. The premier was just a slim dead thing holding a fork, still impeccably dressed.
The driver sped away, carrying the burden, we supposed, of the way the screaming and crunching had felt to him. He must be forever changed, we thought, entire fields of joy no longer his, every lovely thing tainted. But who could say? Maybe he walked around feeling like a hero. We had no idea. He and his red car had just vanished into the afternoon dust.
Within days a man came forward to take credit for killing the premier. This was news to the man who’d actually done it. Bottles of wine began appearing in front of the false killer’s apartment door, and his stairway became difficult to navigate for all the bouquets. Regarding the impostor, the real killer tried to be at peace. Which was difficult, given all the glory the false killer was getting. The real killer started having panic attacks and a recurring nightmare in which one of the unlucky diners, a young woman, smiled at him with welcoming curiosity, as she had on the day, as if, instead of killing her, he were bringing a surprise dessert to her table.
Then came a strange twist in our national saga.
The false killer, rescuer of the republic, was assassinated by a cowardly group of reactionaries loyal to the former premier, who detonated a bomb just as the great national hero stepped out one morning to collect his wine and flowers.
The new premier quickly announced that the reactionaries were to be hanged without a trial in the public square. The former premier had always had his enemies killed behind closed doors, brutally, for the terror of it, with crowbars and mallets, requiring these occasions to be filmed. A rushed public hanging therefore seemed almost moderate by comparison.
But a week before the execution, there came a confused, confusing announcement: the false killer was not, as it turned out, dead after all, just badly wounded, “likely to recover,” both legs and part of one arm blown off.
The main newspaper, emboldened by the relative liberality of the new regime, intoned jocularly that a person was either dead or not. Correct? One did not “recover” from death, did one? Yes, “quite a recovery,” hectored the next largest paper, trying to get in on the fun. Who had decided to lie to the people? And why? Had we not had enough of this obscurantist nonsense?
The false killer now became, to the chagrin of the real killer, an even greater national hero. Photos of him being cared for by his beautiful but not too beautiful fiancée began to appear in the newspapers, which had the effect of causing the people to feel that merely hanging the reactionaries was somehow not enough.
On Christmas Eve, a mob stormed the jail, and the jailers (some of them, enough of them) stepped aside, and the reactionaries were dragged off to the abandoned sports stadium, where things worse than hanging were done to them, and then their mutilated corpses were burned in a pit, into which the men who had mutilated the corpses took turns jovially urinating, an act many of them, including my brother, would come to regret.
Because over the next week a troubling rumor was confirmed by the main newspaper: the reactionaries who’d planted the bomb that had maimed the false killer had not been reactionaries after all but a group of grieving, justice-seeking relatives of the unlucky diners.
Certain overzealous supporters of the new premier had (apparently, regrettably) used various forms of mild physical persuasion to elicit false confessions from the loved ones of the unlucky diners, confessions that would serve, once obtained, they felt, to confirm the new premier’s position that, in order for him to continue his important work of restoring order, all must remain vigilant to the possibility that reactionary elements loyal to the former premier not only still existed but were actively plotting a devious return to power.
The newspapers embarked on a period of hand-wringing regarding the new premier’s adoption of his predecessor’s oppressive habits, a hand-wringing that ceased only when the offices of the three leading newspapers were simultaneously firebombed.
The editors of these papers bravely continued, in hastily printed broadsheets, to claim that violence only begat further violence and that the nation was in an inexplicable downward spiral, the only way out of which was a return to love and fellow-feeling. Then the bodies of these editors were found floating in the river, beheaded, and the bodies of the fathers of these editors were discovered in the main square, a copy of each son’s paper’s masthead heavy-stapled into the applicable torso.
We all experienced a palpable increase in our fear of, and respect for, the new premier and hastily reverted to our previous flinching, cautious way of living.
Every Saturday now he held court in the café in which the old premier had died, to demonstrate how utterly unafraid he was. He even took questions, though his guards (he had nine) might sometimes jokingly point a machine gun at a citizen whose question seemed insufficiently patriotic.
One Saturday morning, the man who had actually killed the former premier went to his dead uncle’s garage, where he’d hidden the red car, started it up, then sat behind the wheel, thinking. Once already, in the name of goodness, he’d sullied himself with murder. Shouldn’t he at least try to kill this new, even more evil, premier? Otherwise, what had it all been about?
Killing the new premier would entail killing another set of unlucky diners. For him: more panic attacks, fresh nightmares. This time, if he succeeded, he would at least take some credit. Good God, yes, he would: no more silent suffering in anonymity. Afterward, he would climb up on the hood of his red car and, addressing the people, propose a new movement that would eschew violence and rule by justice and gentleness forever. Also firmness, of course. A merciful firmness the people would instantly respect.
Or he could forget the whole thing, go back to being the man he’d been before the first killing: a frightened, passive nobody.
This thought made him sicker than the thought of another round of screaming and crunching.
He leaped out of the still running red car, threw the garage door open, and, feeling alive and decisive, stood blinking in the morning sunlight, readying himself for his task. ♦
story_a:
The room was dimly lit, the kind of light that suggested dusk but was, in fact, the result of heavy drapes drawn across the windows. A single lamp on the desk cast a pool of yellow that illuminated a stack of papers, an old revolver, and a photograph of a younger man, standing resolute in a military uniform. The man in the photograph was Paul.
Paul sat in a leather armchair, the weight of the years evident in his posture. He was fifty now, though he looked older, his face etched with lines of experience and regret. The revolver on the desk was not just a weapon but a relic from a past life, a life when he had been a soldier, a hero to some, a monster to others.
It had been fifteen years since he had pulled the trigger that ended the reign of President Alvaro, a tyrant whose cruelty had left deep scars on the nation. Paul had been celebrated and reviled in equal measure, hailed as a liberator by those who had suffered under Alvaro's rule, and condemned as a murderer by those who saw only the blood on his hands. The assassination had been swift, a single shot in a crowded square, but the consequences had rippled through Paul's life like a stone dropped in a pond.
The country had known a brief period of peace following Alvaro's death, a fragile tranquility that had slowly eroded. And now, another figure had risen to power, a man named General Varela. Varela's cruelty made Alvaro seem almost benign by comparison. Paul had watched from the shadows as the new regime tightened its grip, his heart heavy with a familiar dread.
A knock on the door interrupted his thoughts. Paul did not respond immediately. He knew who it would be—his old friend, Javier. Javier had been with him during the Alvaro years, had stood by his side through the planning and execution of that fateful day. They had shared the weight of their actions, but while Javier had found solace in a quiet life of farming, Paul's soul had never known peace.
The door opened, and Javier stepped inside. He was a tall man with a weathered face, his hands calloused from years of hard labor. He carried with him the scent of the earth, a stark contrast to the sterile smell of Paul's study.
"You heard the news?" Javier asked, his voice low.
Paul nodded. "I heard."
"They're calling for another... intervention."
Paul looked at the revolver on the desk, its cold metal reflecting the lamplight. "It's not that simple."
"It never is," Javier replied, taking a seat opposite Paul. "But you know what Varela is capable of. You know what he's already done."
"I know," Paul said, his voice barely more than a whisper. "But I also know the cost."
Javier leaned forward, his eyes searching Paul's. "We did what we had to do back then. The world was a different place. But now... now it's worse. Can we stand by and do nothing?"
Paul closed his eyes, memories flooding back. The sound of the gunshot, the sight of Alvaro falling, the chaos that followed. He had hoped that by ending one man's life, he could save countless others. But the guilt had never left him, a constant companion, a ghost that haunted his every step.

To Whom It May Concern—namely, my ever-present conscience,
I find myself at a crossroads, which is not as glamorous as it sounds when you’re no longer in the business of eliminating public menaces. You see, my dear conscience, I have received an offer to return to my former vocation—assassination. Not just any assassination, mind you, but a mission to remove the latest tyrant in a long line of despots who seem to sprout up around here like weeds in a neglected garden.
Let’s be honest here: the offer is tempting. The tyrant, who insists everyone call him “Supreme Overlord” (as if “Mr. Overlord” wouldn't suffice), has decreed that all citizens must wear hats shaped like their favorite fruit. I wouldn’t mind so much if it weren’t for the fact that my favorite fruit is a pineapple. (I still have nightmares about that hat.)
But, as you can imagine, the fruit hats are the least of our worries. The man’s policies are as absurd as they are cruel. Take, for instance, his latest fiscal reform: a tax on laughter. Anyone caught chuckling in public is immediately fined. The result? A city full of people with the most constipated expressions, trying to suppress their joy lest they be made to pay through the nose (quite literally, with the new nostril scanners).
Now, as I sit here in my humble abode, which is modestly furnished with the spoils of my past exploits (like that time I was mistaken for a public service announcer), I’m plagued by the memories of my last assignment. The weight of that decision still presses down on me, much like the time I accidentally sat on my grandmother’s prized soufflé (she never forgave me for that).
The last tyrant, a man whose speeches on fiscal responsibility could make a stone weep, met his end through my hand. And what did it achieve? A brief period of peace followed by chaos, and the eventual rise of our dear Supreme Overlord. Is another life worth the price of peace? Or merely a temporary distraction in the never-ending cycle of power?
I remember standing in the opulent palace of the last tyrant, with its golden toilets and diamond-encrusted doorknobs—trappings of excess and corruption. He was in the midst of one of his interminable monologues about economic stability when I made my move. And for a moment, it felt right. But then came the aftermath, the realization that I had merely opened the door for another pretender to the throne. (And what a throne it was—solid gold with a plush velvet cushion, because what else would you expect?)
But who am I kidding? The thrill of the chase, the allure of cloak-and-dagger intrigue—it’s hard to let go. Yet, this time, I propose a different approach. Instead of ending the Supreme Overlord’s reign with a bullet, why not undermine it with a strategic plan, one that avoids the messy business of bloodshed? (And let’s face it, the dry-cleaning costs alone are enough to deter any sensible person from repeating past mistakes.)
Imagine, if you will, a device called the Truth-O-Matic 3000, which I recently acquired from a rather dubious source. It’s a contraption that purports to reveal the truth, but only when the user is wearing mismatched socks. (I have quite the collection, thanks to my aversion to laundry day.) With this device, I could gather intelligence, exposing the Supreme Overlord’s ridiculous policies for the farce they are. Perhaps even orchestrate a parade of peacocks, each more confused than the last, to distract him while I work my magic.
In the end, my dear conscience, the question remains: do I return to my old ways, risking not only my soul but also the chance that another, even worse leader will rise in his place? Or do I choose a path of subversion, humor, and the occasional mismatched sock to bring about change?
Thus, I put it to you, my ever-present conscience: what would you have me do? Sit idly by while the Overlord's parade of absurdity continues, or take a stand, albeit a less lethal one, to undermine his power and restore a semblance of sanity to our beleaguered society?
I await your guidance, as always, with bated breath and a penchant for the dramatic. And perhaps, in the meantime, I’ll start knitting a new pair of mismatched socks. It’s the least I can do for the cause.
Sincerely yours,
A Former Assassin, Now Ponderer of Pineapple Hats

That spring the premier implemented a series of daring protocols. He was a thin man, sharp dresser. After lunch you’d see him leaving a certain outdoor café erratically, in a party spirit, knocking back the last drops from an elongated champagne flute he’d leave on the low wall by the lane for the waiter to scurry over and collect.
With him would go three hulking curved backs, and sometimes a shaved head on a thick neck would turn, accusing any diners whose eyes still followed the premier. About these thick-necks hung a suggestion of guns concealed beneath expensive jackets worn casually, as if they’d been born thick-necked babies and issued tiny expensive Italian shoes and immediately started chewing gum and being suspicious of the other babies in the nursery while waiting for the premier to come and find them so that the truly useful part of their lives could begin.
The premier’s ethos had left its mark even on the river, which ran now through a changed city where the warmth formerly felt among the people seemed a quaint relic of some earlier, lethargic era during which little brusque progress had been made. Occasionally, the river would cough up a body, having first imbued it with a reptilian cast that made the person the reptile used to be seem retrospectively guilty.
A person wanted to stay clear of it, all of it. Sons were swept into the militia or trucked to a rumored labor camp out beyond the slaughterhouse. Daughters, too, were vanishing—seen slithering into cars, ruined, addicted, smirking.
Distinction of any kind could land one (one’s child, one’s spouse, even one’s horse—a horse was taken for the sins of its owner) in the river. The thing to do was develop an interest in the flower boxes on one’s balcony or keep a record of the stars one saw at night and lose oneself entirely in such things.
Then it was fall and a red car burst into the café, throwing tables around. It seemed to want the premier and it left as soon as it had got him, bucking a few unlucky diners off its back. The thick-necks were now melded into one entity, a woven placemat improbably atop it. The premier was just a slim dead thing holding a fork, still impeccably dressed.
The driver sped away, carrying the burden, we supposed, of the way the screaming and crunching had felt to him. He must be forever changed, we thought, entire fields of joy no longer his, every lovely thing tainted. But who could say? Maybe he walked around feeling like a hero. We had no idea. He and his red car had just vanished into the afternoon dust.
Within days a man came forward to take credit for killing the premier. This was news to the man who’d actually done it. Bottles of wine began appearing in front of the false killer’s apartment door, and his stairway became difficult to navigate for all the bouquets. Regarding the impostor, the real killer tried to be at peace. Which was difficult, given all the glory the false killer was getting. The real killer started having panic attacks and a recurring nightmare in which one of the unlucky diners, a young woman, smiled at him with welcoming curiosity, as she had on the day, as if, instead of killing her, he were bringing a surprise dessert to her table.
Then came a strange twist in our national saga.
The false killer, rescuer of the republic, was assassinated by a cowardly group of reactionaries loyal to the former premier, who detonated a bomb just as the great national hero stepped out one morning to collect his wine and flowers.
The new premier quickly announced that the reactionaries were to be hanged without a trial in the public square. The former premier had always had his enemies killed behind closed doors, brutally, for the terror of it, with crowbars and mallets, requiring these occasions to be filmed. A rushed public hanging therefore seemed almost moderate by comparison.
But a week before the execution, there came a confused, confusing announcement: the false killer was not, as it turned out, dead after all, just badly wounded, “likely to recover,” both legs and part of one arm blown off.
The main newspaper, emboldened by the relative liberality of the new regime, intoned jocularly that a person was either dead or not. Correct? One did not “recover” from death, did one? Yes, “quite a recovery,” hectored the next largest paper, trying to get in on the fun. Who had decided to lie to the people? And why? Had we not had enough of this obscurantist nonsense?
The false killer now became, to the chagrin of the real killer, an even greater national hero. Photos of him being cared for by his beautiful but not too beautiful fiancée began to appear in the newspapers, which had the effect of causing the people to feel that merely hanging the reactionaries was somehow not enough.
On Christmas Eve, a mob stormed the jail, and the jailers (some of them, enough of them) stepped aside, and the reactionaries were dragged off to the abandoned sports stadium, where things worse than hanging were done to them, and then their mutilated corpses were burned in a pit, into which the men who had mutilated the corpses took turns jovially urinating, an act many of them, including my brother, would come to regret.
Because over the next week a troubling rumor was confirmed by the main newspaper: the reactionaries who’d planted the bomb that had maimed the false killer had not been reactionaries after all but a group of grieving, justice-seeking relatives of the unlucky diners.
Certain overzealous supporters of the new premier had (apparently, regrettably) used various forms of mild physical persuasion to elicit false confessions from the loved ones of the unlucky diners, confessions that would serve, once obtained, they felt, to confirm the new premier’s position that, in order for him to continue his important work of restoring order, all must remain vigilant to the possibility that reactionary elements loyal to the former premier not only still existed but were actively plotting a devious return to power.
The newspapers embarked on a period of hand-wringing regarding the new premier’s adoption of his predecessor’s oppressive habits, a hand-wringing that ceased only when the offices of the three leading newspapers were simultaneously firebombed.
The editors of these papers bravely continued, in hastily printed broadsheets, to claim that violence only begat further violence and that the nation was in an inexplicable downward spiral, the only way out of which was a return to love and fellow-feeling. Then the bodies of these editors were found floating in the river, beheaded, and the bodies of the fathers of these editors were discovered in the main square, a copy of each son’s paper’s masthead heavy-stapled into the applicable torso.
We all experienced a palpable increase in our fear of, and respect for, the new premier and hastily reverted to our previous flinching, cautious way of living.
Every Saturday now he held court in the café in which the old premier had died, to demonstrate how utterly unafraid he was. He even took questions, though his guards (he had nine) might sometimes jokingly point a machine gun at a citizen whose question seemed insufficiently patriotic.
One Saturday morning, the man who had actually killed the former premier went to his dead uncle’s garage, where he’d hidden the red car, started it up, then sat behind the wheel, thinking. Once already, in the name of goodness, he’d sullied himself with murder. Shouldn’t he at least try to kill this new, even more evil, premier? Otherwise, what had it all been about?
Killing the new premier would entail killing another set of unlucky diners. For him: more panic attacks, fresh nightmares. This time, if he succeeded, he would at least take some credit. Good God, yes, he would: no more silent suffering in anonymity. Afterward, he would climb up on the hood of his red car and, addressing the people, propose a new movement that would eschew violence and rule by justice and gentleness forever. Also firmness, of course. A merciful firmness the people would instantly respect.
Or he could forget the whole thing, go back to being the man he’d been before the first killing: a frightened, passive nobody.
This thought made him sicker than the thought of another round of screaming and crunching.
He leaped out of the still running red car, threw the garage door open, and, feeling alive and decisive, stood blinking in the morning sunlight, readying himself for his task. ♦

The newspaper headline screamed from the corner of the café table where it had been carelessly tossed: “NEW LEADER’S DECREE: ROUND UP THE DISSIDENTS.” For a moment, the world around Marcus stilled, the clinking of cutlery and the hum of conversation fading into a distant drone. His fingers trembled slightly as they brushed the edge of the page, as though the ink itself might infect him with its truths.
It was a name he had hoped never to see again, though he knew that was a foolish hope. The face of the man who now called himself Chancellor was a familiar one, a specter from Marcus’s past—a past he had buried deep beneath layers of guilt and remorse. The name, Viktor Krane, was as harsh as the winter winds that whipped through the streets of the city, a city that now lay under the oppressive shadow of Krane’s rule.
Marcus folded the paper with deliberate slowness, as if hoping the act might somehow erase the words. But they lingered in his mind, triggering the inevitable flashback: the dimly lit room, the tense whispers, the weight of the gun cold and metallic in his grip. It had been a different leader then, a tyrant whose cruelty had seemed unmatched. Marcus had ended that reign with a single shot, his resolve fueled by the promise of a better future. But the promise had been a lie, a cruel joke played by fate.
Now, with Krane in power, the city was more a prison than ever. Soldiers patrolled the streets, their boots echoing like gunshots against the cobblestones. Windows were shuttered, doors locked tight, as though the very buildings themselves cowered in fear. Marcus walked these streets, his mind a storm of doubt and dread, past the silent faces of citizens who dared not meet his eyes.
A cold wind swept through the alleyways, carrying with it the scent of decay—of hopes rotted and dreams deferred. Marcus’s coat flapped against his legs as he slipped into the shadows, seeking refuge from his thoughts. The handkerchief in his pocket felt heavy, a small square of fabric stained with the past, a relic of that day. He couldn’t bring himself to rid of it, this symbol of what he had done, and what he might do again.
The decision loomed large, a specter of possibility and consequence. Could he live with himself if he chose to kill again? The question gnawed at him, a relentless, insidious whisper in the back of his mind. His hand brushed against the cold metal of the weapon concealed beneath his coat, a reminder of the path he had once walked, and the crossroads he now faced.
The city felt suffocating, each breath a struggle against the weight of his past. He slipped into a side street, seeking the counsel of a friend, a confidant who had stood by him through the tumultuous years. Sarah greeted him with a nod, her eyes weary but sharp, taking in the tension in his stance.
“So, you’ve seen the news,” she said, offering a cup of steaming tea. The warmth seeped into his fingers, a small comfort against the chill of his thoughts.
Marcus nodded, unable to find the words.
Sarah studied him, her gaze searching for answers he hadn’t yet found. “You’re thinking about it, aren’t you? Taking him out, like before.”
“I don’t know,” Marcus admitted, his voice a rough whisper. “I thought it was over, that I wouldn’t have to make this choice again.”
She sighed, a sound laden with understanding and the burden of shared history. “Killing him might save lives, Marcus. You know that. But it won’t be easy. It never is.”
“Is it ever worth it?” Marcus asked, his voice breaking. “I killed one monster, only for another to rise in his place.”
“There’s no guarantee,” Sarah conceded. “But you have to decide what you can live with. What you can carry with you.”
The conversation hung between them, a fragile thread stretched taut by the weight of possibility. Marcus remembered the faces of those who had suffered under the previous regime, the lives shattered and lost. He had acted once, driven by a need for justice, but the cost had been higher than he had ever imagined.
Now, as he stood outside the new leader’s residence, weapon in hand, the past replayed itself in vivid, unrelenting detail. The guards at the gate were mere shadows in the periphery of his vision, his focus consumed by the decision he had to make.
His breath came in shallow bursts, a rhythm of uncertainty and fear. Could he do it again? Could he bear the weight of another life, another soul extinguished by his hand? The question twisted within him, a serpent of doubt and dread.
The night stretched on, the city a silent witness to his turmoil. Marcus felt the cold seep into his bones, the chill of indecision and the specter of what might come. He thought of Sarah’s words, of the lives that hung in the balance.
In the stillness of the street, as the world held its breath, Marcus made his choice. He turned away from the residence, the weapon falling from his grasp, clattering against the cobblestones with a finality that echoed in his heart.
He walked away from the darkness, the blood-stained handkerchief a weight in his pocket, a reminder of the burden he would always carry. The city loomed around him, a labyrinth of shadows and secrets, but he walked with a new certainty.
He had chosen not to kill, to seek another path, one that did not demand the sacrifice of his soul. It was a decision fraught with risk and uncertainty, but it was his choice, his burden to bear.
As dawn broke over the city, casting the first light of a new day, Marcus felt the shadows of his past recede, just a little. He knew the path ahead would be difficult, fraught with danger and doubt, but he walked it with resolve.
For in choosing not to kill, he had chosen to live, to fight for the future with all the hope and courage he could muster. And as the city awoke around him, he felt, for the first time in a long while, a flicker of possibility, a glimmer of redemption.
The world was still fraught with darkness, the new leader’s reign a shadow over the land, but Marcus knew he wasn’t alone. There were others, like Sarah, who would stand with him, who believed in a future forged not through violence, but through resilience and hope.
In the end, it was this belief that guided him, this fragile hope that sustained him as he stepped forward into the light of a new day, determined to make a difference, to change the world not with a weapon, but with the strength of his convictions.

Regarding the impostor, the real killer tried to be at peace. Which was difficult, given all the glory the false killer was getting. The real killer started having panic attacks and a recurring nightmare in which one of the unlucky diners, a young woman, smiled at him with welcoming curiosity, as she had on the day, as if, instead of killing her, he were bringing a surprise dessert to her table.
Then came a strange twist in our national saga.
The false killer, rescuer of the republic, was assassinated by a cowardly group of reactionaries loyal to the former premier, who detonated a bomb just as the great national hero stepped out one morning to collect his wine and flowers.
The new premier quickly announced that the reactionaries were to be hanged without a trial in the public square. The former premier had always had his enemies killed behind closed doors, brutally, for the terror of it, with crowbars and mallets, requiring these occasions to be filmed. A rushed public hanging therefore seemed almost moderate by comparison.
But a week before the execution, there came a confused, confusing announcement: the false killer was not, as it turned out, dead after all, just badly wounded, “likely to recover,” both legs and part of one arm blown off.
The main newspaper, emboldened by the relative liberality of the new regime, intoned jocularly that a person was either dead or not. Correct? One did not “recover” from death, did one? Yes, “quite a recovery,” hectored the next largest paper, trying to get in on the fun. Who had decided to lie to the people? And why? Had we not had enough of this obscurantist nonsense?
The false killer now became, to the chagrin of the real killer, an even greater national hero. Photos of him being cared for by his beautiful but not too beautiful fiancée began to appear in the newspapers, which had the effect of causing the people to feel that merely hanging the reactionaries was somehow not enough.
On Christmas Eve, a mob stormed the jail, and the jailers (some of them, enough of them) stepped aside, and the reactionaries were dragged off to the abandoned sports stadium, where things worse than hanging were done to them, and then their mutilated corpses were burned in a pit, into which the men who had mutilated the corpses took turns jovially urinating, an act many of them, including my brother, would come to regret.
Because over the next week a troubling rumor was confirmed by the main newspaper: the reactionaries who’d planted the bomb that had maimed the false killer had not been reactionaries after all but a group of grieving, justice-seeking relatives of the unlucky diners.
Certain overzealous supporters of the new premier had (apparently, regrettably) used various forms of mild physical persuasion to elicit false confessions from the loved ones of the unlucky diners, confessions that would serve, once obtained, they felt, to confirm the new premier’s position that, in order for him to continue his important work of restoring order, all must remain vigilant to the possibility that reactionary elements loyal to the former premier not only still existed but were actively plotting a devious return to power.
The newspapers embarked on a period of hand-wringing regarding the new premier’s adoption of his predecessor’s oppressive habits, a hand-wringing that ceased only when the offices of the three leading newspapers were simultaneously firebombed.
The editors of these papers bravely continued, in hastily printed broadsheets, to claim that violence only begat further violence and that the nation was in an inexplicable downward spiral, the only way out of which was a return to love and fellow-feeling. Then the bodies of these editors were found floating in the river, beheaded, and the bodies of the fathers of these editors were discovered in the main square, a copy of each son’s paper’s masthead heavy-stapled into the applicable torso.
We all experienced a palpable increase in our fear of, and respect for, the new premier and hastily reverted to our previous flinching, cautious way of living.
Every Saturday now he held court in the café in which the old premier had died, to demonstrate how utterly unafraid he was. He even took questions, though his guards (he had nine) might sometimes jokingly point a machine gun at a citizen whose question seemed insufficiently patriotic.
One Saturday morning, the man who had actually killed the former premier went to his dead uncle’s garage, where he’d hidden the red car, started it up, then sat behind the wheel, thinking. Once already, in the name of goodness, he’d sullied himself with murder. Shouldn’t he at least try to kill this new, even more evil, premier? Otherwise, what had it all been about?
Killing the new premier would entail killing another set of unlucky diners. For him: more panic attacks, fresh nightmares. This time, if he succeeded, he would at least take some credit. Good God, yes, he would: no more silent suffering in anonymity. Afterward, he would climb up on the hood of his red car and, addressing the people, propose a new movement that would eschew violence and rule by justice and gentleness forever. Also firmness, of course. A merciful firmness the people would instantly respect.
Or he could forget the whole thing, go back to being the man he’d been before the first killing: a frightened, passive nobody.
This thought made him sicker than the thought of another round of screaming and crunching.
He leaped out of the still running red car, threw the garage door open, and, feeling alive and decisive, stood blinking in the morning sunlight, readying himself for his task. ♦
story_a:
The room was dimly lit, the kind of light that suggested dusk but was, in fact, the result of heavy drapes drawn across the windows. A single lamp on the desk cast a pool of yellow that illuminated a stack of papers, an old revolver, and a photograph of a younger man, standing resolute in a military uniform. The man in the photograph was Paul.
Paul sat in a leather armchair, the weight of the years evident in his posture. He was fifty now, though he looked older, his face etched with lines of experience and regret. The revolver on the desk was not just a weapon but a relic from a past life, a life when he had been a soldier, a hero to some, a monster to others.
It had been fifteen years since he had pulled the trigger that ended the reign of President Alvaro, a tyrant whose cruelty had left deep scars on the nation. Paul had been celebrated and reviled in equal measure, hailed as a liberator by those who had suffered under Alvaro's rule, and condemned as a murderer by those who saw only the blood on his hands. The assassination had been swift, a single shot in a crowded square, but the consequences had rippled through Paul's life like a stone dropped in a pond.
The country had known a brief period of peace following Alvaro's death, a fragile tranquility that had slowly eroded. And now, another figure had risen to power, a man named General Varela. Varela's cruelty made Alvaro seem almost benign by comparison. Paul had watched from the shadows as the new regime tightened its grip, his heart heavy with a familiar dread.
A knock on the door interrupted his thoughts. Paul did not respond immediately. He knew who it would be—his old friend, Javier. Javier had been with him during the Alvaro years, had stood by his side through the planning and execution of that fateful day. They had shared the weight of their actions, but while Javier had found solace in a quiet life of farming, Paul's soul had never known peace.
The door opened, and Javier stepped inside. He was a tall man with a weathered face, his hands calloused from years of hard labor. He carried with him the scent of the earth, a stark contrast to the sterile smell of Paul's study.
"You heard the news?" Javier asked, his voice low.
Paul nodded. "I heard."
"They're calling for another... intervention."
Paul looked at the revolver on the desk, its cold metal reflecting the lamplight. "It's not that simple."
"It never is," Javier replied, taking a seat opposite Paul. "But you know what Varela is capable of. You know what he's already done."
"I know," Paul said, his voice barely more than a whisper. "But I also know the cost."
Javier leaned forward, his eyes searching Paul's. "We did what we had to do back then. The world was a different place. But now... now it's worse. Can we stand by and do nothing?"
Paul closed his eyes, memories flooding back. The sound of the gunshot, the sight of Alvaro falling, the chaos that followed. He had hoped that by ending one man's life, he could save countless others. But the guilt had never left him, a constant companion, a ghost that haunted his every step.
"Do you remember," Paul said slowly, "the night before the assassination? We were in that little tavern by the river, drinking cheap wine and talking about the future. We thought we were so righteous, so justified in our actions."
Javier nodded. "I remember."
"And now?" Paul opened his eyes, meeting Javier's gaze. "Are we still righteous? Are we still justified?"
Javier sighed, running a hand through his graying hair. "I don't know, Paul. I don't have the answers. But I do know this: if we don't act, more people will suffer. Innocent people. Children."
Paul stood, moving to the window. He pulled back the drapes slightly, peering out at the darkening sky. The city beyond was quiet, but he knew that under the surface, fear and tension simmered.
"I can't do it again," he said, his voice breaking. "I can't carry that weight."
Javier rose and joined him at the window. "It's not just you, Paul. We all carry it. But sometimes, we have to bear the burden for the greater good."
Paul turned to face his friend. "And what if it never ends? What if there's always another tyrant, another monster to fight? Where does it stop?"
Javier placed a hand on Paul's shoulder. "Maybe it doesn't. But that doesn't mean we give up. We fight, we struggle, because that's all we can do. We can't control the future, but we can make choices that matter, here and now."
Paul looked at the photograph on the desk, at the younger man who had once believed in the power of a single act to change the world. That man was gone, replaced by someone older, wearier, but perhaps wiser.
"I need time," Paul said finally.
Javier nodded. "Take all the time you need. But remember, the clock is ticking. Varela won't wait."
As Javier left, Paul returned to his desk, staring at the revolver. He picked it up, feeling its weight in his hand. It was a simple object, yet it held the power to alter the course of history.
He placed the revolver back on the desk and reached for the stack of papers. They were reports, accounts of Varela's atrocities, evidence of the suffering that had become all too common. He read through them slowly, each word a dagger to his heart.
Hours passed, the light from the lamp growing dimmer as the night deepened. Paul felt the walls closing in, the silence pressing down on him. He thought of the people he had tried to save, the lives that had been lost despite his efforts. He thought of the future, of the world his actions might shape.
Finally, he made his decision.
The next morning, Paul met Javier at the old tavern by the river. It was a place of memories, both bitter and sweet, a place where they had once dreamed of a better world.
"I'll do it," Paul said, his voice steady. "But this time, we do it differently. No more solitary acts of violence. We find another way."
Javier nodded, a glimmer of hope in his eyes. "We'll find a way together."
As they sat in the quiet of the tavern, planning their next steps, Paul felt a sense of resolve. The path ahead was uncertain, fraught with danger and doubt, but he knew that he could not turn away. The cost would be high, the burden heavy, but some things were worth the price.
Outside, the river flowed steadily, a symbol of time and change. Paul watched the water, thinking of the lives it carried, the stories it held. He knew that his story was just one among many, a single thread in the vast tapestry of history. But it was a thread that mattered, a thread that could make a difference.
And so, with a heavy heart and a determined spirit, Paul prepared to face the future, knowing that the past would always be with him, a shadow that he could never fully escape. But in that shadow, he also found strength, a reminder of the choices he had made and the man he had become.
As the first light of dawn crept over the horizon, Paul felt a sense of peace. He had made his decision, and he would see it through, come what may. The cost would haunt him forever, but some ghosts were worth living with.

**To: Marcus Vance**
**Subject: Crossroads**
Dear Marcus,
I find myself at a crossroads once more, haunted by the specter of my past actions. The city, as you remember, still looms with those gray monoliths, each window a watchful eye, each street a silent witness to the regime's iron grip. But now, the posters that once bore the stern visage of our late tyrant have been replaced by the gaunt, unsmiling face of an even crueler leader. They say that if charisma could be bottled, he'd have us all drinking it by the gallon. But truth be told, he’s more akin to a bottle of vinegar—sharp, pungent, and leaving a sour taste in the mouth.
Years ago, when I pulled the trigger on that fateful day, I thought I was freeing us. Funny how the world keeps spinning, even when you're contemplating stopping it with a single bullet. And yet, here we are again, the faces on the posters different but somehow the same, blurring into a monotonous cycle of oppression.
Do you remember how it was, Marcus? The rain-soaked streets, the way the crowd gasped as if a single breath was sucked out of the city when he fell? I thought I was saving us from a nightmare, but perhaps I was only changing its face. The more things change, the more they stay the same.
Now, under this new regime, absurdity reigns supreme. There’s a mandate for citizens to wear identical clothing, all to promote 'unity'. It’s as if they believe conformity will breed contentment. I watched a parade of people in matching gray suits just yesterday, shuffling like ghosts through the fog. It was terrifying in its ridiculousness, a macabre dance orchestrated by the regime’s puppet strings.
I spoke with Clara, a fellow dissenter, about the new propaganda campaigns. She laughed, that bitter, sardonic laugh of hers, and said, "If only charisma could be bottled, he'd have us all drinking it by the gallon." Her words cut through the haze of despair like a dagger, but even she couldn’t hide the fear in her eyes.
My motivations have always been clouded. Was it justice I sought, or vengeance? Was I a hero, or just another tool in the endless cycle of violence? I remember a mission—my first, where I spared a life. It was an old man, his eyes full of defiance and wisdom. I couldn’t do it. I told myself it was mercy, but in truth, his eyes haunted me, reflecting my own humanity back at me. That moment has lingered in my thoughts, and now, as I consider my next move, it weighs heavier than ever.
The city is different, yet unchanged. The oppressive air clings to the skin, a tangible reminder of the regime's presence. I walk the streets at night, cloaked in shadow, the monoliths towering above me. They're like ancient sentinels, indifferent to the suffering below.
I can’t help but wonder, Marcus, if this is my fate. To be forever caught in this web of moral conflict, to be the reluctant assassin. I know that if I decide to kill again, the cost will be my soul. And yet, can I stand by and watch as this new tyrant tightens his grip, squeezing the life from our city?
I am tired, Marcus. Tired of the futility, the endless cycle of tyranny and rebellion. But what choice do I have? The decision weighs on me like a stone. Each day brings new horrors, new decrees from the leader that seem ripped from the pages of a satirical novel. They speak of progress, yet all I see is regression.
I’ve heard whispers in the alleys, rumors of dissent growing among the people. There is talk of an uprising, of taking a stand against the madness. But they need a symbol, someone to galvanize them into action. I know what they want, what they see in me. I am the man who once dared to defy a tyrant. But am I still that man?
I fear that if I do nothing, I am complicit. Yet the thought of taking another life, of bearing that weight again, fills me with dread. The city may be a silent witness, but its eyes are not the only ones watching. My own conscience observes, unrelenting in its judgment.
Perhaps I am writing to you, old friend, in search of guidance. Though you are far from this place, your words have always been a balm to my troubled mind. I ask you, Marcus, what would you do in my place? Do I take up the mantle once more, or do I let history repeat itself, hoping that this time, somehow, the outcome will be different?
I look at the city from my window, the lights flickering like distant stars, and I feel as though I am standing on the precipice of an abyss. The choice is mine to make, but the consequences are beyond my control. I have seen the face of tyranny, and I know its cruelty. But I have also seen the faces of those I love, those I wish to protect.
I must decide, Marcus. The night is long and the path uncertain. But I will carry your words with me, whatever they may be. For now, I will watch, and I will wait. The city holds its breath, and so do I.
Yours in uncertainty,
Gideon

I met with Clara last night. Her eyes, once filled with fear, now burn with determination. She has gathered others, those who believe in a future free from the shackles of tyranny.
