prompt: When Arthur stumbles upon the scars Merlin has been hiding, he demands answers—but the truth behind them reveals more than either of them expected, leaving their bond forever changed.
ground_truth:
“Scars are just another kind of memory.” - M.L. Stedman
It was his own stupid fault, Merlin thought grimly. His usual clumsiness and an unguarded moment was all it took.
He had been helping set up for Uther's latest stupid feast, and he'd slopped red wine all down the front of a blue tunic. In theory, he could have dismissed the stain with a spell, but the smell would have haunted him all evening. Arthur might know that all the time he was apparently in the tavern he was dealing with some magical crisis or other, but the same could not be said for the rest of the court. His reputation was bad enough as it was without adding fuel to that particular fire.
He'd ducked into one of the rooms where they stored the fresh laundry, pulling free a tunic he'd not yet collected before peeling himself free of the clinging fabric. The rustle of cloth meant he didn't hear the creak of the door, and the voice that rang out behind him made him jolt in surprise.
'What happened to your back?'
Arthur's voice sounded tense, stiff and uncertain. The brush of warm fingers against the three, pale lines across his shoulder-blade made Merlin jolt in alarm. He whirled around, the tunic still clutched in his hands as he blinked stupidly, his words caught somewhere in his throat.
Not that it mattered. Arthur was too busy staring at the starburst scar the size of a grown man's hand that lay right in the centre of his front, over his heart. A frown of confusion melted beneath a mask of horror, and Merlin swallowed hard as all the colour fled Arthur's face.
'What happened to your chest?!'
'Er...' Merlin winced, because although he had told Arthur about his magic – about everything he had done in his name, the good and the bad – he had rather glossed over some of the details. He hadn't done any of it for Arthur's gratitude, after all. He didn't need his thanks or his sympathy, but he couldn't deny that some of his choices had left their marks on his body for the world to see.
'Why are you in here?' he managed, hoping to derail the conversation as he hastily tugged on the fresh garment, shoving his arms through the sleeves as he hid the scars from sight. 'Did you need something?'
'I need you to tell me what happened.' Arthur's blue eyes snapped with an aimless, volatile sort of anger. His arms were folded across his chest, making his tunic strain at the shoulders, and the scowl on his brow suggested he wouldn't be easily swayed from his questioning. 'Merlin, who hurt you?'
'It was ages ago. It doesn't matter.'
He went to duck around Arthur, mumbling something about the feast preparations. Yet before he got more than a few paces, strong fingers snagged his wrist. It wasn't a tight grip, Merlin could have broken free with ease, but he still came to heel like a dog obeying its master.
'No, I'm not letting you leave,' he murmured, the rumble of his words sending a bolt of heat arcing down Merlin's spine. It snatched the air from his lungs, leaving him breathless and tense as Arthur turned him back around, shifting his grip to Merlin's shoulders as he stared into his eyes. 'Not until you tell me the truth. Who. Hurt. You?'
The anger in that expression wasn't aimed at him; Merlin knew that well enough. There was nothing Arthur hated more than feeling helpless. He was protective of his knights where Uther was dismissive of their loyalty and their sacrifice, but the gleam in his eye went beyond that. Dread had stolen the warmth from his face, and he was watching Merlin with the kind of intensity that some would find unnerving.
'Sigan and his stupid gargoyles' – He jerked his thumb over his shoulder, indicating the scars on his back before tapping one finger over his heart – 'Nimueh and a fireball.' They were such simple words for the horror of stony claws raking his back and the flash and burn of the incendiary spell that had hit him square in the chest, but in the end, they summed it up pretty neatly. 'It's fine, Arthur. They healed.'
He frowned, not understanding the expression on Arthur's face. The knights took injuries for him all the time, and while he praised their courage, he never looked like that – as if someone had reached into his guts and wrenched them out of him, leaving him hollow.
'That's not the point.' Arthur's grasp moved from his shoulders, drifting down his arms to his hands. It was a soothing gesture, one Merlin wasn't even sure was consciously done. Yet even he could feel how Arthur's touch mapped the calluses on his palms and the small scars that were an apprentice healer's mark: tiny burns and the occasional slim white line where the herb-knife had slipped and sliced skin instead. Those didn't cause him any distress, and Merlin realised it was because they were expected: wounds received in the execution of his duties.
Duties which, even knowing about his magic, Arthur clearly didn't realise involved protecting him with as much determination as any one of his knights.
'You've got scars,' Merlin pointed out, thinking of the starburst from the Questing Beast's bite, among others.
'I'm a knight. A prince.' He didn't add "a target"; he didn't have to. They were both thinking it. 'I've been trained to fight since I could walk. You... haven't.'
Merlin snorted. That was an understatement. Still, he could practically see the spin of considerations in Arthur's head, and some magical sense forewarned him that if he didn't speak quickly, he'd find himself on the duelling field being beaten half-to-death in the name of "practice".
'Wielding a sword wouldn't have saved me from either of these, and it's not like I can train in battle-spells, is it?' He shrugged one shoulder, unwilling to disturb Arthur's hand from where it still gripped his, tracing idle, tormenting little patterns against his skin. He didn't think Arthur realised what he was doing: how each caress made Merlin's breath come from deeper in his chest. It made his heart feel like it pumped hot honey, rather than blood, around his veins. 'It's not exactly discreet.'
Arthur pulled as face, but he didn't argue. It had been slow, steady work, getting him to see just how much damage the ban on magic had caused. Arthur would not care for his own sake: he was not interested in doing anything the easy way, but he was beginning to see how his people could suffer from its lack. Now, he looked at Merlin with fresh realisation. 'You can't learn how to defend yourself. Not without risking exposing your magic to all of Camelot.'
It was a flat statement of fact, one that he could not deny. It wasn't just that he could not practice; even studying the theory was a risky endeavour. As long as Uther still sat upon the throne, then Merlin had to work from the shadows and hope that he and Arthur both survived to see better days.
'Armour.' Arthur said it softly. 'I cannot change the laws of Camelot, but there's is nothing to say a servant cannot wear armour. You could enchant it, couldn't you? Extra spells to protect you from magic. You've done it to mine.' One golden eyebrow lifted in challenge, as if daring Merlin to deny it. 'No one will question it. They know you come on almost every patrol with us, and more than one person has remarked upon the fact that you do not wear anything but the tunic on your back. Truthfully, I should have done something about that long before now.'
Merlin pursed his lips. The rumours in court were already rife, and armour would just be another sign of his favour. Already, people noticed how Arthur let Merlin get away with disobedience that bordered on treason, sometimes, and they had taken note.
It was tempting to argue: to say he didn't need it. Armour wouldn't protect him from magical attacks, but he could see the desperation in Arthur's gaze. Those eyes had dipped to the laces of Merlin's tunic, as if envisioning the scar beneath. There was a haunted slant to his expression, as if he were imagining how that day could have ended.
The hand around Merlin's tightened, firm and sure, and when Arthur lifted his eyes once more, he looked resolute. 'I won't see you hurt again,' he said, speaking like a king laying down the law. 'Not if I can help it. One day, it will be different.' He swallowed. 'One day, you will be able to practice your magic without having to hide, but for now, let me help keep you safe. Please?'
Merlin blinked, his heart heaving in a dizzying whirl. Arthur had never spoken of this before. He almost couldn't believe his ears, and he shifted where he stood, one hand reaching out as if he could pin Arthur's words – this very moment – motionless in place.
'Do you mean it?' he rasped, trying to fight the urge to lean forward but unable to stop himself. 'You'll return magic to Camelot?'
'Yes.' Arthur tilted his head to the side, a faint smile curving his lips at whatever he saw in Merlin's face. 'I swear it.'
Beyond the door, the sounds of hurrying servants broke through the heavy air between them. It was enough to send a ripple of awareness through the tiny room – to make Merlin realise how close they stood to each other. All around them the balance of their friendship seemed to wobble, breathless, but it was Merlin, not Arthur, who stepped back in retreat.
'I – I don't know what to say.' A grin spread over his face, bright and unstoppable. 'Thank you!'
And if he hadn't already loved Arthur for more months than he cared to count – hidden and unacknowledged – he would have fallen there and then to see Arthur's bright, boyish grin light up the room.
'You're welcome, Merlin.'
Buckles chimed as Arthur slid them into place, sheathing Merlin in the armour he had commissioned. It was not the glittering mail and stalwart plate of his knights, but soft leather with scale pressed between: light and flexible, but strong enough to shield Merlin from the worst the world had to offer.
He wet his lips, looking up at him under his lashes as his pulse thrummed helplessly. The promise he had made still echoed in his mind. No doubt accompanied it; he would not go back on his word. Not after he'd seen the vicious light of hope lend its glow to Merlin's features.
Besides, magic was not the only thing he planned to change when he took the throne. He could not admit how he felt for Merlin now, not while his father still lived and all the expectations of the court were against them. He would not make Merlin suffer that.
Instead, he did what he could to protect the man who had stolen his heart. He would keep him safe in whatever way he could, and one day, he would be free to claim the love that Merlin promised him with every glance.
They would have their golden age, together. Arthur would make sure of it.
story_a:
Arthur hadn’t meant to find out. In fact, he had been oblivious to the secret Merlin had carried for years, hidden beneath layers of cheerful banter and clumsy servitude. It was only when Merlin had slipped, quite literally, during one of their training sessions, that Arthur had glimpsed the truth.
Merlin had been attempting to dodge one of Arthur’s playful swipes, an effort to keep the prince on his toes, but his foot had caught on the uneven ground. He’d gone down hard, the impact tearing his tunic and baring his back for the briefest of moments. That moment was all it took for Arthur to see the scars—jagged, angry lines crisscrossing Merlin’s pale skin.
“Merlin!” Arthur’s voice was sharp, tinged with an emotion he couldn’t quite place. “What are those?”
Merlin scrambled to his feet, hastily pulling his tunic back into place. “Nothing, Sire. Just old wounds.”
“Old wounds?” Arthur’s eyes narrowed. “They look fresh. Who did this to you?”
“It’s nothing,” Merlin insisted, but his eyes betrayed him. They were wide, filled with a mix of fear and something else—something that looked a lot like shame.
“Merlin, I command you to tell me,” Arthur said, his voice dropping to a softer, yet no less authoritative tone. “Who did this to you?”
Merlin hesitated, his gaze dropping to the ground. “It’s a long story,” he muttered.
Arthur crossed his arms over his chest, his expression unyielding. “I’m not going anywhere.”
With a heavy sigh, Merlin sat down on a nearby log, the firelight casting shadows across his face. “It’s not just one person,” he began, his voice barely above a whisper. “It’s... it’s magic.”
Arthur’s heart skipped a beat. “Magic?”
Merlin nodded, his eyes meeting Arthur’s with a mixture of defiance and resignation. “I’ve been hiding it for years. Ever since I came to Camelot. But... but these scars, they’re from the times I couldn’t hide it. When I had to use magic to protect you, to protect Camelot.”
Arthur’s mind raced, piecing together fragments of memories, moments that had never quite made sense until now. “You’ve been using magic? For me?”
“Yes,” Merlin admitted, his voice breaking. “I know it’s forbidden, but I couldn’t let you die. I couldn’t let Camelot fall.”
For a moment, Arthur was silent, the weight of Merlin’s confession settling over him like a heavy cloak. “Why didn’t you tell me?” he asked finally, his voice thick with emotion.
“Because I knew what you’d say,” Merlin replied, his eyes glistening with unshed tears. “I knew you’d hate me.”
Arthur’s heart ached at the raw vulnerability in Merlin’s voice. “I could never hate you,” he said softly. “You’re my friend. My best friend.”
Merlin looked up, hope flickering in his eyes. “Really?”
“Really,” Arthur affirmed. He reached out, placing a hand on Merlin’s shoulder. “But I need to understand, Merlin. I need to know everything.”
And so, Merlin began to tell him. He spoke of the dragon Kilgharrah, of the prophecies and the destiny that had bound them together from the start. He spoke of the countless times he had used magic to save Arthur’s life, of the dangers he had faced and the sacrifices he had made. And as he spoke, Arthur listened, his heart swelling with a mixture of pride and sorrow.
When Merlin finally fell silent, Arthur felt as though he had been handed the pieces of a puzzle he hadn’t even known existed. “You’ve done so much for me,” he said, his voice filled with awe. “And I never knew.”
“I didn’t want you to know,” Merlin said quietly. “I didn’t want you to have to carry that burden.”
“But it’s not just your burden,” Arthur replied firmly. “We’re in this together. We always have been.”
Merlin’s eyes widened, a tentative smile tugging at the corners of his mouth. “Together?”
“Together,” Arthur repeated, his tone leaving no room for doubt. “From now on, we face everything together. No more secrets.”
Merlin nodded, a sense of peace washing over him for the first time in years. “No more secrets.”

The bond between them had been tested, but it had emerged stronger than ever. And he knew, without a doubt, that they could face whatever challenges lay ahead—together.

It was a mundane task, but Arthur saw it differently now. He saw the sacrifices Merlin had made, the risks he had taken, all while performing the duties of a simple servant.
“Merlin,” Arthur called out, approaching him.
Merlin looked up, his expression wary. “Yes, Sire?”
Arthur shook his head. “No more of that. Just Arthur.”
Merlin’s eyes widened in surprise. “Arthur?”
“Yes,” Arthur said firmly. “We’re equals, Merlin. You’ve proven that time and time again.”
Merlin’s lips curved into a hesitant smile. “Thank you, Arthur.”
Arthur nodded, a smile of his own forming. “Now, I have a proposition for you.”
“Oh?” Merlin’s curiosity was piqued.
“I want you to be my advisor,” Arthur said, his tone leaving no room for argument. “You know more about magic and destiny than anyone. And I need someone I can trust by my side.”
Merlin’s mouth fell open in shock. “Advisor? But... but what about—”
“Father?” Arthur finished for him. “We’ll deal with him together. He needs to understand that magic isn’t inherently evil. And who better to show him than you?”
Merlin’s heart swelled with gratitude and pride. “I’d be honored, Arthur.”
“Good,” Arthur said, clapping him on the back. “Now, let’s get to work. We have a kingdom to protect.”
As they walked towards the castle, side by side, Merlin couldn’t help but feel a sense of hope. For the first time, he wasn’t alone in his fight. Arthur knew the truth, and he still stood by him. It was more than Merlin had ever dared to dream.

Weeks turned into months, and Arthur and Merlin’s bond only grew stronger. They faced countless challenges together, from rogue sorcerers to political intrigue, but they always emerged victorious. Arthur’s trust in Merlin never wavered, and Merlin found himself more confident in his magic and his place by Arthur’s side.
One evening, as they sat in Arthur’s chambers, poring over maps and strategies, Arthur looked up, his expression thoughtful. “Do you ever regret it?” he asked suddenly.
“Regret what?” Merlin replied, glancing up from the map.
“Everything,” Arthur said, gesturing vaguely. “The magic, the secrets, the danger. Do you ever wish you could have a normal life?”
Merlin considered the question, his gaze distant. “Sometimes,” he admitted. “But then I remember why I’m doing it. I remember you, and Camelot, and everything we’ve built together. And I know it’s worth it.”
Arthur’s eyes softened. “Thank you, Merlin. For everything.”
Merlin smiled, a warm, genuine smile. “You don’t have to thank me, Arthur. I’m just doing what I was meant to do.”
Arthur reached across the table, grasping Merlin’s hand. “And I’m grateful for it. Every day.”
In that moment, as their hands clasped together, Arthur knew that their bond was unbreakable. They had faced the darkness and emerged into the light, stronger and more united than ever. And as long as they stood together, there was nothing they couldn’t overcome.
---
The news spread quickly through the castle: Arthur had appointed Merlin as his advisor. Reactions were mixed, but Arthur stood firm in his decision. He faced his father with unwavering resolve, explaining the truth about Merlin’s magic and the countless times it had saved them all.
King Uther was furious, but Arthur’s determination and Merlin’s unwavering loyalty eventually won him over. It wasn’t an easy transition, but slowly, the people of Camelot began to see the benefits of having a sorcerer in their midst.
Merlin’s knowledge of magic became an invaluable asset, and his presence by Arthur’s side brought a new sense of hope to the kingdom. Together, they worked to create a more just and fair Camelot, one where magic wasn’t feared but respected.
As the years passed, Arthur and Merlin’s bond only deepened. They faced trials and tribulations, but they always came out stronger on the other side. Their friendship was the foundation upon which Camelot’s future was built, and it was a future filled with promise and possibility.
One night, as they stood on the castle battlements, looking out over the kingdom they had fought so hard to protect, Arthur turned to Merlin with a smile. “Do you remember the day I found out about your magic?”

Arthur laughed. “I almost did. But I’m glad I didn’t.”
“Me too,” Merlin said, his voice filled with gratitude.
Arthur’s expression turned serious. “I want you to know, Merlin, that I wouldn’t be here without you. Camelot wouldn’t be here without you.”
Merlin’s eyes shone with emotion. “And I wouldn’t be here without you, Arthur. You’ve given me a place, a purpose. You’ve given me a home.”
Arthur reached out, pulling Merlin into a tight embrace. “We’ve given each other everything,” he said softly. “And as long as we stand together, there’s nothing we can’t achieve.”
As they stood there, wrapped in each other’s warmth, the future stretched out before them—bright, hopeful, and filled with endless possibilities. And they knew, without a doubt, that they would face it all together, side by side, as they always had.
For in the end, it wasn’t the magic or the destiny that defined them. It was their bond, their friendship, and the unbreakable trust they had in each other. And that, above all else, was what made them unstoppable.

The sun had barely risen over Camelot, its golden rays filtering through the narrow windows of Arthur's chambers, casting long shadows across the stone floor. The morning was still, holding a promise of quiet that was rare in the bustling castle. Arthur, half-dressed and wrestling with his tunic, was already grumbling about the day's duties when Merlin entered, carrying the prince's cloak.
“Honestly, Merlin, if you spent half as much time tending to your duties as you do daydreaming, I might actually have a cloak that doesn’t smell like horse,” Arthur quipped, a smirk playing at his lips.
Merlin rolled his eyes, a familiar banter between them. “If you spent half as much time being a decent human being as you do swinging that sword around, you might not need me to fetch your clothes at all.”
Arthur chuckled, reaching out to tug the cloak from Merlin’s hands. But his playful motion was interrupted as the fabric slipped, catching on Merlin's arm, pulling his sleeve up in a swift motion.
The room froze. Arthur’s breath caught in his throat as his eyes fell upon the scars that crisscrossed Merlin’s forearm, stark against his pale skin. They were not the simple marks of a childhood mishap or the result of an accident in the kitchens. These were deliberate, harsh reminders of something much darker.
“Merlin,” Arthur said, his voice low, a mixture of confusion and concern, “what happened?”
Merlin’s eyes widened, and he hastily pulled down his sleeve, turning away as if to hide his shame. “It’s nothing,” he mumbled, but the tremor in his voice betrayed him.
“Nothing?” Arthur repeated, stepping closer, his voice growing more insistent. “Those scars—Merlin, they’re not nothing. Tell me the truth.”
There was a long pause, the silence between them heavy with unspoken words. Merlin turned back, meeting Arthur’s gaze with a look that held centuries of secrets. He sighed, a sound filled with the weight of worlds. “You really want to know?”
Arthur nodded, his expression earnest, the teasing prince replaced by the king he was destined to be. “I do.”
Merlin hesitated, then nodded towards the small wooden chair by the window. “You might want to sit.”
Once Arthur was settled, Merlin took a deep breath, gathering his courage. “These scars,” he began, rolling up his sleeve again to reveal the lines that marked his skin, “are from a time when I had to make a choice.”
Arthur frowned, his mind racing with possibilities. “A choice?”
Merlin nodded. “They’re from a battle—a battle not many knew took place. It was long before I came to Camelot, in a village on the edge of Albion. There was a sorcerer, one who had turned dark, twisted by his own power. He was terrorizing the people, and they were desperate.”
Arthur listened, his blue eyes locked onto Merlin, absorbing every word. “And you fought him?”
“I had to,” Merlin replied, his voice soft, a touch of old pain lacing his words. “He was destroying everything, everyone. I couldn’t stand by and watch.”
“But why the scars?” Arthur asked, his brow furrowing as he tried to piece together the story.
Merlin looked down at his arm, tracing one of the lines with a fingertip. “Magic leaves marks, Arthur. When two powerful forces clash, it’s not just the environment that suffers. It’s the people too. These scars are a reminder of the power I used, and the cost of it.”
Arthur’s gaze softened, understanding beginning to dawn. “You saved them, didn’t you? The villagers?”
Merlin nodded, his eyes distant, as if seeing that day again. “I did. But it wasn’t without a price.”
The room was quiet, the only sound the distant calls of the morning guard. Arthur leaned back in his chair, processing everything he’d learned. “You’ve carried this alone all this time?”
Merlin shrugged, a small, rueful smile on his lips. “It’s not exactly something I can talk about freely, is it?”
“No,” Arthur agreed, his voice soft with newfound empathy. “I suppose not.”
There was a pause, then Arthur leaned forward, his expression earnest. “Merlin, I’m sorry. I didn’t know.”
Merlin waved a hand, brushing off the apology. “How could you? I’ve done my best to keep it hidden.”
“Why?” Arthur asked, genuine curiosity in his voice. “Why keep it from me?”
Merlin met his gaze, his expression serious. “Because I was afraid, Arthur. Afraid of what you might think. Afraid of what might happen if the truth came out.”
Arthur shook his head, a small smile tugging at his lips. “You should know by now that I’m not that easy to scare off.”
Merlin chuckled, the sound lighter now, the tension between them easing. “No, you’re more stubborn than that.”
They shared a look, a silent understanding passing between them, one that spoke of forgiveness and acceptance. Arthur stood, reaching out to clasp Merlin’s shoulder. “Thank you for telling me. It means a lot.”
Merlin nodded, a warmth spreading through him at the sincerity in Arthur’s voice. “Thank you for listening.”
Arthur’s gaze lingered on Merlin’s scars, the lines of history etched into his skin. They were a testament to the battles Merlin had fought, not just for himself, but for others. It was a reminder of the hidden burdens he carried, the strength beneath his unassuming exterior.
“Do they still hurt?” Arthur asked, a note of concern in his voice.
“Sometimes,” Merlin admitted. “But it’s a small price to pay.”
Arthur nodded, his respect for Merlin deepening. “You’re braver than anyone gives you credit for.”
Merlin smiled, a genuine smile that reached his eyes. “I think you’re the first person to ever say that.”
Arthur grinned, clapping him on the back. “Then it’s about time someone did.”
As they stood there, side by side, the morning light bathing the room in a gentle glow, something shifted between them. The truth had been laid bare, and with it, a new understanding was forged. Their bond, once built on loyalty and friendship, was now strengthened by trust and shared secrets.
Merlin glanced at Arthur, a question in his eyes. “So, what now?”
Arthur shrugged, a mischievous glint in his eye. “Now, we get on with the day. After all, I need my cloak, and you need to make sure I don’t end up wearing it inside out.”
Merlin laughed, the sound clear and bright, a new beginning in its tone. “Alright, alright. But don’t blame me if you trip over it later.”
Arthur chuckled, taking the cloak from Merlin and fastening it with practiced ease. “I’ll try not to.”
As they left the chamber, stepping into the bustling life of the castle, the scars remained. But they were no longer just marks of past battles; they were symbols of the trust that now bound them, reminders of the courage it took to reveal the truth.
In the weeks that followed, Merlin found himself more at ease, the weight of his secrets no longer as heavy. Arthur, too, seemed different, more open, more willing to share the burdens of his own destiny.
One evening, as they sat by the fire in Arthur’s chambers, the crackling flames casting flickering shadows on the walls, Arthur spoke up, his voice contemplative. “You know, Merlin, I’ve been thinking.”
“Dangerous pastime,” Merlin teased, earning a playful swat from Arthur.
“I’m serious,” Arthur insisted, his tone thoughtful. “About what you said, about the cost of magic.”
Merlin turned to face him, curiosity piqued. “What about it?”
Arthur met his gaze, his expression solemn. “I’ve always thought of magic as something dangerous, something to be feared. But now... now I see it’s more complicated than that.”
Merlin nodded, understanding the struggle within Arthur. “Magic is a tool, Arthur. It can be used for good or ill. It’s the person wielding it who makes the difference.”
Arthur mulled over his words, the flames reflecting in his eyes. “And you’ve always chosen to use it for good.”
“I try,” Merlin replied, his voice humble.
Arthur smiled, a warmth in his eyes that spoke of admiration. “You’ve done more than try, Merlin. You’ve succeeded.”
Merlin felt a swell of gratitude, the acknowledgment meaning more than he could express. “Thank you, Arthur.”
Arthur leaned back, a contented sigh escaping him. “I’m glad we had that talk.”
“Me too,” Merlin agreed, a sense of peace settling over him.
As the night wore on, they spoke of other things—of knights and quests, of dreams and futures. But beneath it all, the scars remained a silent testament to their shared journey, a reminder of the trust they had built.
In the quiet moments, when the castle slept and the world seemed still, Merlin would sometimes trace the lines on his arm, feeling the ridges beneath his fingertips. They were a part of him, a part of his story. And now, they were a part of Arthur’s too.
The discovery of the scars had changed everything, but it had also brought them closer. It had forged a bond that was unbreakable, one that would endure through trials and triumphs alike.
For Arthur and Merlin, the journey was far from over. There would be challenges ahead, battles to be fought and won. But whatever came, they would face it together, side by side, their friendship stronger than ever.
And as they stood on the battlements of Camelot, looking out over the land they both loved, they knew that whatever scars the future might bring, they would bear them with courage and pride, knowing they were not alone.
In the end, the scars were not just marks of past struggles; they were symbols of hope, of resilience, of the enduring power of friendship.
And for Arthur and Merlin, that was more than enough.

“Scars are just another kind of memory.” - M.L. Stedman
It was his own stupid fault, Merlin thought grimly. His usual clumsiness and an unguarded moment was all it took.
He had been helping set up for Uther's latest stupid feast, and he'd slopped red wine all down the front of a blue tunic. In theory, he could have dismissed the stain with a spell, but the smell would have haunted him all evening. Arthur might know that all the time he was apparently in the tavern he was dealing with some magical crisis or other, but the same could not be said for the rest of the court. His reputation was bad enough as it was without adding fuel to that particular fire.
He'd ducked into one of the rooms where they stored the fresh laundry, pulling free a tunic he'd not yet collected before peeling himself free of the clinging fabric. The rustle of cloth meant he didn't hear the creak of the door, and the voice that rang out behind him made him jolt in surprise.
'What happened to your back?'
Arthur's voice sounded tense, stiff and uncertain. The brush of warm fingers against the three, pale lines across his shoulder-blade made Merlin jolt in alarm. He whirled around, the tunic still clutched in his hands as he blinked stupidly, his words caught somewhere in his throat.
Not that it mattered. Arthur was too busy staring at the starburst scar the size of a grown man's hand that lay right in the centre of his front, over his heart. A frown of confusion melted beneath a mask of horror, and Merlin swallowed hard as all the colour fled Arthur's face.
'What happened to your chest?!'
'Er...' Merlin winced, because although he had told Arthur about his magic – about everything he had done in his name, the good and the bad – he had rather glossed over some of the details. He hadn't done any of it for Arthur's gratitude, after all. He didn't need his thanks or his sympathy, but he couldn't deny that some of his choices had left their marks on his body for the world to see.
'Why are you in here?' he managed, hoping to derail the conversation as he hastily tugged on the fresh garment, shoving his arms through the sleeves as he hid the scars from sight. 'Did you need something?'
'I need you to tell me what happened.' Arthur's blue eyes snapped with an aimless, volatile sort of anger. His arms were folded across his chest, making his tunic strain at the shoulders, and the scowl on his brow suggested he wouldn't be easily swayed from his questioning. 'Merlin, who hurt you?'
'It was ages ago. It doesn't matter.'
He went to duck around Arthur, mumbling something about the feast preparations. Yet before he got more than a few paces, strong fingers snagged his wrist. It wasn't a tight grip, Merlin could have broken free with ease, but he still came to heel like a dog obeying its master.
'No, I'm not letting you leave,' he murmured, the rumble of his words sending a bolt of heat arcing down Merlin's spine. It snatched the air from his lungs, leaving him breathless and tense as Arthur turned him back around, shifting his grip to Merlin's shoulders as he stared into his eyes. 'Not until you tell me the truth. Who. Hurt. You?'
The anger in that expression wasn't aimed at him; Merlin knew that well enough. There was nothing Arthur hated more than feeling helpless. He was protective of his knights where Uther was dismissive of their loyalty and their sacrifice, but the gleam in his eye went beyond that. Dread had stolen the warmth from his face, and he was watching Merlin with the kind of intensity that some would find unnerving.
'Sigan and his stupid gargoyles' – He jerked his thumb over his shoulder, indicating the scars on his back before tapping one finger over his heart – 'Nimueh and a fireball.' They were such simple words for the horror of stony claws raking his back and the flash and burn of the incendiary spell that had hit him square in the chest, but in the end, they summed it up pretty neatly. 'It's fine, Arthur. They healed.'
He frowned, not understanding the expression on Arthur's face. The knights took injuries for him all the time, and while he praised their courage, he never looked like that – as if someone had reached into his guts and wrenched them out of him, leaving him hollow.
'That's not the point.' Arthur's grasp moved from his shoulders, drifting down his arms to his hands. It was a soothing gesture, one Merlin wasn't even sure was consciously done. Yet even he could feel how Arthur's touch mapped the calluses on his palms and the small scars that were an apprentice healer's mark: tiny burns and the occasional slim white line where the herb-knife had slipped and sliced skin instead. Those didn't cause him any distress, and Merlin realised it was because they were expected: wounds received in the execution of his duties.
Duties which, even knowing about his magic, Arthur clearly didn't realise involved protecting him with as much determination as any one of his knights.
'You've got scars,' Merlin pointed out, thinking of the starburst from the Questing Beast's bite, among others.
'I'm a knight. A prince.' He didn't add "a target"; he didn't have to. They were both thinking it. 'I've been trained to fight since I could walk. You... haven't.'
Merlin snorted. That was an understatement. Still, he could practically see the spin of considerations in Arthur's head, and some magical sense forewarned him that if he didn't speak quickly, he'd find himself on the duelling field being beaten half-to-death in the name of "practice".
'Wielding a sword wouldn't have saved me from either of these, and it's not like I can train in battle-spells, is it?' He shrugged one shoulder, unwilling to disturb Arthur's hand from where it still gripped his, tracing idle, tormenting little patterns against his skin. He didn't think Arthur realised what he was doing: how each caress made Merlin's breath come from deeper in his chest. It made his heart feel like it pumped hot honey, rather than blood, around his veins. 'It's not exactly discreet.'
Arthur pulled as face, but he didn't argue. It had been slow, steady work, getting him to see just how much damage the ban on magic had caused. Arthur would not care for his own sake: he was not interested in doing anything the easy way, but he was beginning to see how his people could suffer from its lack. Now, he looked at Merlin with fresh realisation. 'You can't learn how to defend yourself. Not without risking exposing your magic to all of Camelot.'
It was a flat statement of fact, one that he could not deny. It wasn't just that he could not practice; even studying the theory was a risky endeavour. As long as Uther still sat upon the throne, then Merlin had to work from the shadows and hope that he and Arthur both survived to see better days.
'Armour.' Arthur said it softly. 'I cannot change the laws of Camelot, but there's is nothing to say a servant cannot wear armour. You could enchant it, couldn't you? Extra spells to protect you from magic. You've done it to mine.' One golden eyebrow lifted in challenge, as if daring Merlin to deny it. 'No one will question it. They know you come on almost every patrol with us, and more than one person has remarked upon the fact that you do not wear anything but the tunic on your back. Truthfully, I should have done something about that long before now.'
Merlin pursed his lips. The rumours in court were already rife, and armour would just be another sign of his favour. Already, people noticed how Arthur let Merlin get away with disobedience that bordered on treason, sometimes, and they had taken note.
It was tempting to argue: to say he didn't need it. Armour wouldn't protect him from magical attacks, but he could see the desperation in Arthur's gaze. Those eyes had dipped to the laces of Merlin's tunic, as if envisioning the scar beneath. There was a haunted slant to his expression, as if he were imagining how that day could have ended.
The hand around Merlin's tightened, firm and sure, and when Arthur lifted his eyes once more, he looked resolute. 'I won't see you hurt again,' he said, speaking like a king laying down the law. 'Not if I can help it. One day, it will be different.' He swallowed. 'One day, you will be able to practice your magic without having to hide, but for now, let me help keep you safe. Please?'
Merlin blinked, his heart heaving in a dizzying whirl. Arthur had never spoken of this before. He almost couldn't believe his ears, and he shifted where he stood, one hand reaching out as if he could pin Arthur's words – this very moment – motionless in place.
'Do you mean it?' he rasped, trying to fight the urge to lean forward but unable to stop himself. 'You'll return magic to Camelot?'
'Yes.' Arthur tilted his head to the side, a faint smile curving his lips at whatever he saw in Merlin's face. 'I swear it.'
Beyond the door, the sounds of hurrying servants broke through the heavy air between them. It was enough to send a ripple of awareness through the tiny room – to make Merlin realise how close they stood to each other. All around them the balance of their friendship seemed to wobble, breathless, but it was Merlin, not Arthur, who stepped back in retreat.
'I – I don't know what to say.' A grin spread over his face, bright and unstoppable. 'Thank you!'
And if he hadn't already loved Arthur for more months than he cared to count – hidden and unacknowledged – he would have fallen there and then to see Arthur's bright, boyish grin light up the room.
'You're welcome, Merlin.'
Buckles chimed as Arthur slid them into place, sheathing Merlin in the armour he had commissioned. It was not the glittering mail and stalwart plate of his knights, but soft leather with scale pressed between: light and flexible, but strong enough to shield Merlin from the worst the world had to offer.
He wet his lips, looking up at him under his lashes as his pulse thrummed helplessly. The promise he had made still echoed in his mind. No doubt accompanied it; he would not go back on his word. Not after he'd seen the vicious light of hope lend its glow to Merlin's features.
Besides, magic was not the only thing he planned to change when he took the throne. He could not admit how he felt for Merlin now, not while his father still lived and all the expectations of the court were against them. He would not make Merlin suffer that.
Instead, he did what he could to protect the man who had stolen his heart. He would keep him safe in whatever way he could, and one day, he would be free to claim the love that Merlin promised him with every glance.
They would have their golden age, together. Arthur would make sure of it.

The flickering light from the dying fire cast shadows that danced across the stone walls of Arthur’s chambers, lending the room an intimacy that was both comforting and claustrophobic. The evening had worn on with the quiet companionship of two friends, and Merlin, ever the diligent servant, had fallen asleep in the chair by the hearth, a book of ancient remedies slipping from his fingers to land softly on the rug.
Arthur, returning from his own quiet contemplation by the window, paused at the sight. Merlin was rarely still, and in repose, the lines of weariness were stark on his face. Arthur's gaze, normally sharp and assessing, softened. It was then that he noticed it—a thin line of scar tissue peeking just above the collar of Merlin's tunic, exposed as he shifted in his sleep.
Curiosity, that persistent companion, nudged at Arthur's mind. He knelt down, careful not to wake his friend, and gently tugged the fabric aside to reveal more of the scar. It was ragged and old, a ghostly line that whispered of violence and pain long past. His breath caught, a mix of shock and anger tightening his chest. What had Merlin been hiding?
In that moment, the room seemed to shrink around him. The prince's mind raced, piecing together fragments of memory—times Merlin had returned from errands with excuses that rang hollow, moments when he had flinched at a casual touch or dismissed his own discomfort with a practiced smile. Each recollection was a piece of a puzzle Arthur had never realized existed.
"Merlin," he called, his voice low but insistent, rousing his friend from slumber.
Merlin stirred, blinking groggily. "Arthur?" He sat up, rubbing sleep from his eyes, and then froze under the prince's scrutinizing gaze. "What is it?"
Arthur gestured to the scar, now plainly visible. "This," he said, his voice a mixture of demand and concern. "Where did it come from?"
Merlin's hand flew to his collar, a flicker of panic crossing his features before he masked it with a smile that didn't reach his eyes. "Oh, that? Just an old accident. Nothing to worry about."
"An accident?" Arthur's tone was sharp, incredulous. "Merlin, that's not just a scratch. And it's not the only one, is it?"
The room was silent save for the crackling of the fire. Merlin looked away, his expression troubled. Arthur's frustration mounted, mingling with a worry that gnawed at his insides. "Why didn't you tell me?" he pressed, softer now, the anger tempered by a note of pleading.
Merlin hesitated, the weight of unspoken truths pressing down on him. "Because some battles are fought alone," he murmured, his voice barely above a whisper.
Arthur's heart clenched at the words, the quiet admission laden with a depth of sacrifice he hadn't fully comprehended. "Show me," he said, the request gentle but firm, a prince's command softened by friendship.
Reluctantly, Merlin stood and began to unbutton his tunic, the fabric slipping from his shoulders to reveal a tapestry of scars etched across his skin. Each mark was a testament to battles fought in silence, lines of white and silver tracing stories of danger and courage.
Arthur reached out, his fingers hovering just above the scars, as if afraid to touch the history they bore. "Why, Merlin?" he asked, the question laden with a complexity of emotions.
Merlin sighed, the sound heavy with the burden of secrets. "Because it was never just about me. It was about you, about Camelot. About keeping you safe."
Arthur's throat tightened, a mix of awe and guilt swirling within him. "But all of this... you never said a word."
"I couldn't," Merlin replied, meeting Arthur's gaze with a steadiness that belied the turmoil beneath. "There are things you were never meant to know, Arthur. Things I had to keep hidden to protect you, to protect everyone."
Arthur's mind reeled, the implications staggering. Merlin, his friend, his servant, had been carrying this weight alone, fighting battles he hadn't even known were raging. "And the magic?" Arthur asked, the unspoken question finally given voice.
Merlin's eyes darkened with a flicker of fear and defiance. "Yes," he admitted quietly. "Magic."
Arthur's breath caught, the revelation both expected and yet startling in its simplicity. His upbringing screamed of betrayal, of laws and decrees, but his heart, his heart saw only Merlin, standing before him with a vulnerability that demanded understanding.
"I should be angry," Arthur said, his voice rough with emotion. "I should be furious."
"And are you?" Merlin asked, his voice steady but his eyes searching.
Arthur was silent, grappling with the whirlwind of feelings that surged within him. Anger was there, yes, but it was dwarfed by something far greater—admiration, gratitude, a profound sense of connection. "No," he said finally, the word a quiet revelation. "No, I'm not."

“Scars are just another kind of memory.” - M.L. Stedman
It was his own stupid fault, Merlin thought grimly. His usual clumsiness and an unguarded moment was all it took.
He had been helping set up for Uther's latest stupid feast, and he'd slopped red wine all down the front of a blue tunic. In theory, he could have dismissed the stain with a spell, but the smell would have haunted him all evening. Arthur might know that all the time he was apparently in the tavern he was dealing with some magical crisis or other, but the same could not be said for the rest of the court. His reputation was bad enough as it was without adding fuel to that particular fire.
He'd ducked into one of the rooms where they stored the fresh laundry, pulling free a tunic he'd not yet collected before peeling himself free of the clinging fabric. The rustle of cloth meant he didn't hear the creak of the door, and the voice that rang out behind him made him jolt in surprise.
'What happened to your back?'
Arthur's voice sounded tense, stiff and uncertain. The brush of warm fingers against the three, pale lines across his shoulder-blade made Merlin jolt in alarm. He whirled around, the tunic still clutched in his hands as he blinked stupidly, his words caught somewhere in his throat.
Not that it mattered. Arthur was too busy staring at the starburst scar the size of a grown man's hand that lay right in the centre of his front, over his heart. A frown of confusion melted beneath a mask of horror, and Merlin swallowed hard as all the colour fled Arthur's face.
'What happened to your chest?!'
'Er...' Merlin winced, because although he had told Arthur about his magic – about everything he had done in his name, the good and the bad – he had rather glossed over some of the details. He hadn't done any of it for Arthur's gratitude, after all. He didn't need his thanks or his sympathy, but he couldn't deny that some of his choices had left their marks on his body for the world to see.
'Why are you in here?' he managed, hoping to derail the conversation as he hastily tugged on the fresh garment, shoving his arms through the sleeves as he hid the scars from sight. 'Did you need something?'
'I need you to tell me what happened.' Arthur's blue eyes snapped with an aimless, volatile sort of anger. His arms were folded across his chest, making his tunic strain at the shoulders, and the scowl on his brow suggested he wouldn't be easily swayed from his questioning. 'Merlin, who hurt you?'
'It was ages ago. It doesn't matter.'
He went to duck around Arthur, mumbling something about the feast preparations. Yet before he got more than a few paces, strong fingers snagged his wrist. It wasn't a tight grip, Merlin could have broken free with ease, but he still came to heel like a dog obeying its master.
'No, I'm not letting you leave,' he murmured, the rumble of his words sending a bolt of heat arcing down Merlin's spine. It snatched the air from his lungs, leaving him breathless and tense as Arthur turned him back around, shifting his grip to Merlin's shoulders as he stared into his eyes. 'Not until you tell me the truth. Who. Hurt. You?'
The anger in that expression wasn't aimed at him; Merlin knew that well enough. There was nothing Arthur hated more than feeling helpless. He was protective of his knights where Uther was dismissive of their loyalty and their sacrifice, but the gleam in his eye went beyond that. Dread had stolen the warmth from his face, and he was watching Merlin with the kind of intensity that some would find unnerving.
'Sigan and his stupid gargoyles' – He jerked his thumb over his shoulder, indicating the scars on his back before tapping one finger over his heart – 'Nimueh and a fireball.' They were such simple words for the horror of stony claws raking his back and the flash and burn of the incendiary spell that had hit him square in the chest, but in the end, they summed it up pretty neatly. 'It's fine, Arthur. They healed.'
He frowned, not understanding the expression on Arthur's face. The knights took injuries for him all the time, and while he praised their courage, he never looked like that – as if someone had reached into his guts and wrenched them out of him, leaving him hollow.
'That's not the point.' Arthur's grasp moved from his shoulders, drifting down his arms to his hands. It was a soothing gesture, one Merlin wasn't even sure was consciously done. Yet even he could feel how Arthur's touch mapped the calluses on his palms and the small scars that were an apprentice healer's mark: tiny burns and the occasional slim white line where the herb-knife had slipped and sliced skin instead. Those didn't cause him any distress, and Merlin realised it was because they were expected: wounds received in the execution of his duties.
Duties which, even knowing about his magic, Arthur clearly didn't realise involved protecting him with as much determination as any one of his knights.
'You've got scars,' Merlin pointed out, thinking of the starburst from the Questing Beast's bite, among others.
'I'm a knight. A prince.' He didn't add "a target"; he didn't have to. They were both thinking it. 'I've been trained to fight since I could walk. You... haven't.'
Merlin snorted. That was an understatement. Still, he could practically see the spin of considerations in Arthur's head, and some magical sense forewarned him that if he didn't speak quickly, he'd find himself on the duelling field being beaten half-to-death in the name of "practice".
'Wielding a sword wouldn't have saved me from either of these, and it's not like I can train in battle-spells, is it?' He shrugged one shoulder, unwilling to disturb Arthur's hand from where it still gripped his, tracing idle, tormenting little patterns against his skin. He didn't think Arthur realised what he was doing: how each caress made Merlin's breath come from deeper in his chest. It made his heart feel like it pumped hot honey, rather than blood, around his veins. 'It's not exactly discreet.'
Arthur pulled as face, but he didn't argue. It had been slow, steady work, getting him to see just how much damage the ban on magic had caused. Arthur would not care for his own sake: he was not interested in doing anything the easy way, but he was beginning to see how his people could suffer from its lack. Now, he looked at Merlin with fresh realisation. 'You can't learn how to defend yourself. Not without risking exposing your magic to all of Camelot.'
It was a flat statement of fact, one that he could not deny. It wasn't just that he could not practice; even studying the theory was a risky endeavour. As long as Uther still sat upon the throne, then Merlin had to work from the shadows and hope that he and Arthur both survived to see better days.
'Armour.' Arthur said it softly. 'I cannot change the laws of Camelot, but there's is nothing to say a servant cannot wear armour. You could enchant it, couldn't you? Extra spells to protect you from magic. You've done it to mine.' One golden eyebrow lifted in challenge, as if daring Merlin to deny it. 'No one will question it. They know you come on almost every patrol with us, and more than one person has remarked upon the fact that you do not wear anything but the tunic on your back. Truthfully, I should have done something about that long before now.'
Merlin pursed his lips. The rumours in court were already rife, and armour would just be another sign of his favour. Already, people noticed how Arthur let Merlin get away with disobedience that bordered on treason, sometimes, and they had taken note.
It was tempting to argue: to say he didn't need it. Armour wouldn't protect him from magical attacks, but he could see the desperation in Arthur's gaze. Those eyes had dipped to the laces of Merlin's tunic, as if envisioning the scar beneath. There was a haunted slant to his expression, as if he were imagining how that day could have ended.
The hand around Merlin's tightened, firm and sure, and when Arthur lifted his eyes once more, he looked resolute. 'I won't see you hurt again,' he said, speaking like a king laying down the law. 'Not if I can help it. One day, it will be different.' He swallowed. 'One day, you will be able to practice your magic without having to hide, but for now, let me help keep you safe. Please?'
Merlin blinked, his heart heaving in a dizzying whirl. Arthur had never spoken of this before. He almost couldn't believe his ears, and he shifted where he stood, one hand reaching out as if he could pin Arthur's words – this very moment – motionless in place.
'Do you mean it?' he rasped, trying to fight the urge to lean forward but unable to stop himself. 'You'll return magic to Camelot?'
'Yes.' Arthur tilted his head to the side, a faint smile curving his lips at whatever he saw in Merlin's face. 'I swear it.'
Beyond the door, the sounds of hurrying servants broke through the heavy air between them. It was enough to send a ripple of awareness through the tiny room – to make Merlin realise how close they stood to each other. All around them the balance of their friendship seemed to wobble, breathless, but it was Merlin, not Arthur, who stepped back in retreat.
'I – I don't know what to say.' A grin spread over his face, bright and unstoppable. 'Thank you!'
And if he hadn't already loved Arthur for more months than he cared to count – hidden and unacknowledged – he would have fallen there and then to see Arthur's bright, boyish grin light up the room.
'You're welcome, Merlin.'
Buckles chimed as Arthur slid them into place, sheathing Merlin in the armour he had commissioned. It was not the glittering mail and stalwart plate of his knights, but soft leather with scale pressed between: light and flexible, but strong enough to shield Merlin from the worst the world had to offer.
He wet his lips, looking up at him under his lashes as his pulse thrummed helplessly. The promise he had made still echoed in his mind. No doubt accompanied it; he would not go back on his word. Not after he'd seen the vicious light of hope lend its glow to Merlin's features.
Besides, magic was not the only thing he planned to change when he took the throne. He could not admit how he felt for Merlin now, not while his father still lived and all the expectations of the court were against them. He would not make Merlin suffer that.
Instead, he did what he could to protect the man who had stolen his heart. He would keep him safe in whatever way he could, and one day, he would be free to claim the love that Merlin promised him with every glance.
They would have their golden age, together. Arthur would make sure of it.

The morning sun spilled through the high windows of Camelot’s training grounds, painting stripes of gold across the straw-strewn floor. The prince moved with a fluid grace that spoke of countless hours honing his skills, every movement precise and powerful.
"Merlin!" Arthur called, sheathing his sword with a flourish. His servant was late, again, and he was in desperate need of a towel. The knights had dispersed, leaving Arthur standing alone, tapping his foot impatiently against the flagstones.
Merlin appeared moments later, breathless and clutching a bundle of Arthur’s clothes. "Sorry, sire," he mumbled, offering the linen with a sheepish grin. His hair was tousled, and there was a smudge of dirt on his cheek, evidence of some earlier chore.
"You’re late," Arthur chided, though the edge in his voice was softened by familiarity. "Again."
"Only by a minute," Merlin countered, eyes twinkling with mischief. "Besides, you looked like you were having fun without me."
Arthur chuckled, dismissing the knights with a wave. "I suppose I can forgive you. This time." He draped the towel around his shoulders, wiping the sweat from his brow. "But only because I managed to best all my opponents."
Merlin's grin widened. "As if there was any doubt."
It was in that moment, as Arthur turned to head towards his chambers, that he noticed something unusual. The edge of Merlin’s tunic had lifted slightly, revealing a sliver of skin marred by a jagged scar. Arthur paused, his gaze lingering on the mark, curiosity piqued. He knew Merlin had his secrets—everyone did—but this was different. This was tangible, undeniable evidence of a past unknown.
"Merlin," Arthur called, his tone shifting from playful to serious. Merlin halted, sensing the change immediately.
"Yes, sire?" Merlin replied, instinctively pulling his tunic down. But the damage was done; the prince had seen too much, and yet not enough.
Arthur closed the distance between them, his eyes fixed on the fabric concealing the scars. "Where did those come from?" he asked, voice low and edged with concern. "The scars, Merlin."
Merlin hesitated, a flicker of uncertainty crossing his features. He had always been careful, always kept that part of himself hidden. The scars were his stories, etched onto his skin like a map of battles fought in silence. To reveal them was to reveal too much.
"It’s nothing," Merlin said, trying for nonchalance and failing. He looked away, focusing on a point just over Arthur’s shoulder.
"Nothing doesn’t leave marks like that," Arthur insisted, his curiosity now mingled with a protective instinct he couldn’t quite explain. "You owe me the truth, Merlin."
For a moment, Merlin considered brushing it off, conjuring some tale to placate Arthur’s curiosity. But the look in the prince’s eyes stopped him. There was a sincerity there, a genuine concern that pulled at something deep within Merlin.
"Fine," he relented, drawing a breath as if steeling himself for battle. "But not here. Let’s go somewhere... quieter."
Arthur nodded, his curiosity now a palpable force as he followed Merlin through the winding corridors of Camelot, up towards the more secluded part of the castle where Merlin’s chambers lay. The room was small, cluttered with books and herbs, a testament to Merlin’s dual life as a servant and a sorcerer. It was a place of secrets, and today, it would reveal one more.
Merlin closed the door behind them, the latch clicking softly into place. "Alright," he said, turning to face Arthur. "I’ll tell you, but you have to promise to keep an open mind."
Arthur raised an eyebrow, intrigued by the gravity in Merlin’s voice. "You have my word."
Merlin nodded, pulling the tunic over his head to reveal a torso crisscrossed with scars, each one a testament to battles fought and magic wielded. Arthur’s eyes widened, tracing the lines with a mix of awe and horror. "Merlin, what...?"
"They’re from battles," Merlin explained, voice steady but soft. "Not the kind you’re used to, but battles nonetheless. They’re... they’re from magic."
"Magic?" Arthur echoed, the word heavy with the weight of Camelot’s laws against sorcery. "You mean...?"
Merlin nodded, meeting Arthur’s gaze with a mixture of defiance and vulnerability. "I’m a sorcerer, Arthur. I’ve been using magic since the day we met."
Arthur’s mind reeled with the revelation, a thousand thoughts colliding at once. Betrayal, disbelief, and yet, underneath it all, an odd sense of relief. It made sense, in a way, explaining all the strange occurrences and miraculous rescues that had peppered their adventures.
"You’ve been using magic all this time?" Arthur asked, his voice a mixture of accusation and wonder. "Why didn’t you tell me?"
"Because it’s illegal," Merlin replied, a hint of bitterness creeping into his tone. "Because it’s dangerous. For both of us."
Arthur absorbed that, the implications sinking in. Merlin had been risking his life, not just in battle, but every day, living under the constant threat of discovery and execution. And yet, he had done it willingly, for Camelot, for Arthur.
"These scars," Arthur said, gesturing to Merlin’s chest, "they’re from using magic?"
"Some of them," Merlin acknowledged. "Magic has a cost. Sometimes it’s physical, sometimes it’s... more. But they’re also from battles. Protecting you, protecting Camelot."
Arthur felt a swell of emotion, a confusing mix of gratitude and guilt. "You’ve been protecting me all this time," he murmured, more to himself than to Merlin.
Merlin shrugged, a small, self-deprecating smile playing on his lips. "It’s kind of my job."
There was a moment of silence, thick with unspoken words and emotions. Arthur studied Merlin, seeing him anew, not just as a servant or a friend, but as something more. A protector, a confidant, a sorcerer.
"I’m sorry," Arthur said at last, his voice sincere. "For everything. For not seeing it sooner, for... for not understanding."
Merlin shook his head, stepping closer. "You didn’t know. And now you do. That’s what matters."
Arthur reached out, his hand brushing against one of the scars, feeling the raised skin beneath his fingers. It was a mark of sacrifice, of loyalty, of a bond that ran deeper than either had realized. "Thank you," Arthur said, his voice barely above a whisper. "For everything."
Merlin smiled, the tension easing from his shoulders. "We’re a team, remember?"
Arthur nodded, a smile tugging at his lips. "Yes, we are."
The air between them felt lighter somehow, the weight of secrets lifted. Arthur knew that their relationship had changed, irrevocably, but not for the worse. If anything, the revelation had strengthened their bond, weaving trust and understanding into the fabric of their friendship.
"We should probably get back," Merlin suggested, pulling his tunic back on. "Before someone notices we’re missing."
Arthur chuckled, the sound warm and genuine. "Right. And Merlin?"
"Yes?"
"Don’t be late again," Arthur said, his tone teasing but with an undercurrent of affection. "Or I’ll have to start docking your wages."
Merlin laughed, the sound echoing through the small chamber. "You don’t pay me."
"Exactly," Arthur replied, clapping Merlin on the shoulder as they left the room, side by side.
As they made their way back through the castle, Arthur felt a sense of renewal, a hope that despite the challenges ahead, they would face them together. He glanced at Merlin, who was chattering about some new herb Gaius had discovered, and felt an overwhelming sense of gratitude.
For the first time, Arthur understood the true depth of Merlin’s loyalty, and it filled him with a fierce determination to protect his friend, no matter the cost.
In that moment, beneath the vaulted ceilings of Camelot, their bond was rewritten, no longer just prince and servant, but allies, friends. A king and his sorcerer.
And so, with the promise of secrets shared and a future forged in trust, they stepped into the sunlit courtyard, ready to face whatever destiny had in store. Together.

In their minds, are they continuing the previous war, or has some genius at Proxima Centauri or beyond managed to kick open their anthill again? Athanasius shrugged. Ill make one last inspection of the weapons crews. Make sure theyre in fighting trim. Make it quick, Paulus said after him as he exited the bridge. Pressing the transmit button on TBS, he said, All ships, Task Group 40, this is *Sicilia,* over. *Liguria*, over. *Cisalpina,* over. *Sicilia,* the fifth ship in the *Trireme* class, was accompanied by two smaller *Bireme* class ships, the *Liguria* and *Cisalpina.* His task group was a versatile mix of ships well-suited to picket duty, but against a large force like this one, they had little chance of success. The task group was off-station, headed for a scheduled refueling evolution at Orbital Station Neptune, and had been just an hour away from docking when their sensors had picked up light announcing the arrival of the Formic fleet. There wasnt supposed to be a jump point in that portion of the Kuiper belt, so it hadnt been actively patrolled. They had already been in the Sol system three hours before Task Group 40 was even aware they were here. Paulus had turned the group around as soon as they had received the sensor data. Nine ships exhibiting strong blue shift. They were definitely headed toward the inner solar system. Task Group 40 had been on this intercept heading for nearly eleven hours now at a speed of 0.2c, or two tenths the speed of light.
